z:row.TitlePrimary: Asymmetry reversal of ion collection by mach probes in flowing unmagnetized plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Ko, E, Novellus Syst, 4000 N 1st St, San Jose, CA 95134 USA.; eunsuk.ko@novellus.com
z:row.Abstract: Measurements of ion current in flowing unmagnetized plasmas were performed with planar and spherical Mach probes in two different devices, one a dc multi-dipole plasma device for subsonic flow within a presheath region and the other a double plasma device for supersonic flow. Asymmetry reversal, which is higher ion current to the downstream side of the probe compared with the upstream side current, was observed for high probe bias compared with the electron temperature, relatively low ion drift velocity and Debye length comparable to probe radius. These data are in qualitative agreement with a recent numerical calculation by Hutchinson. As suggested by Hutchinson, it was found that the current ratio depended on the plasma parameters, especially for finite Debye length and high probe bias. Asymmetry reversal emphasizes the lack of validity of using the current ratio except for narrow parameter ranges. This study is the first experiment to demonstrate the non-intuitive phenomenon predicted by Hutchinson's numerical calculation.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: CHUNG KS, 1988, PHYS REV A, V38, P4721 CHUNG KS, 1991, J APPL PHYS, V71, P1177 GULICK SL, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V176, P1059 GUNN JP, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 2, V8, P1995 GUREVICH AV, 1969, SPACE SCI REV, V9, P805 HUDIS M, 1970, J APPL PHYS, V41, P5001 HUTCHINSON IH, 1987, PHYS FLUIDS, V30, P3777 HUTCHINSON IH, 2002, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V9, P1832 HUTCHINSON IH, 2002, PLASMA PHYS CONTR F, V44, P1953 HUTCHINSON IH, 2003, PLASMA PHYS CONTR F, V45, P1477 LIMPAECHER R, 1973, REV SCI INSTRUM, V44, P726 OKSUZ L, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V8, P1729 OKSUZ L, 2002, PHYS REV LETT, V89 OKSUZ L, 2004, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V13, P263 PANEK R, 2005, J NUCL MATER, V337, P530 RICCARDI C, 2004, REV SCI INSTRUM 2, V75, P4341 STANGEBY PC, 1984, PHYS FLUIDS, V27, P2699 TAYLOR RJ, 1972, REV SCI INSTRUM, V43, P1675 WEYNANTS RR, 2005, FUSION SCI TECHNOL, V47, P202; NR: 19; TC: 0; J9: PLASMA PHYS CONTROL FUSION; PG: 14; GA: 053TT

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental studies of the two-ion species flow in the plasma presheath
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Wang, X, Univ Colorado, Ctr Integrated Plasma Studies, Boulder, CO 80309 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The ion flow created in the presheath of weakly ionized He+Ar plasma is studied experimentally. Ion acoustic wave measurements combined with previous LIF measurements [Phys. Rev. Lett. 90, 145001 (2003)] suggest that the Ar ion and He ion drift velocities approach each other near the sheath-presheath boundary. Their common velocity is the ion sound velocity of the system. The Ar ion and He ion drift velocities are also calculated assuming mobility-limited flow, including symmetric and asymmetric ion-neutral collisions, combined with the measured plasma potential profile. Comparing these calculations to the wave and LIF data shows that both ion species drift in the presheath with mobility-limited flow until very close to the sheath edge. (c) 2006 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BASURTO E, 2000, PHYS REV E, V61, P3053 BOHM D, 1949, CHARACTERISTICS ELEC, CH3 CONRAD JR, 1987, J APPL PHYS, V62, P4591 FRANKLIN RN, 2000, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V33, P3186 FRANKLIN RN, 2001, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V34, P1959 FRANKLIN RN, 2003, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V36, P1806 HALA AM, 2000, THESIS U WISCONSIN M HERSHKOWITZ N, 2005, IEEE T PLASMA SCI 2, V33, P631 KOIZUMI T, 1979, J PHYS SOC JPN, V47, P1031 LANGMUIR I, 1929, PHYS REV, V33, P954 OKSUZ L, 2002, PHYS REV LETT, V89 RIEMANN KU, 1995, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V23, P709 SEVERN GD, 2003, PHYS REV LETT, V90 SMITH JR, 1979, REV SCI INSTRUM, V50, P210 ZHANG D, 2001, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V19, P524; NR: 15; TC: 0; J9: PHYS PLASMAS; PG: 4; GA: 048JI

z:row.TitlePrimary: Simple way to determine the edge of an electron-free sheath with an emissive probe
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Wang, X, Univ Colorado, Ctr Integrated Plasma Studies, Boulder, CO 80309 USA.
z:row.Abstract: A new technique to determine the edge of an electron-free sheath is presented. The technique takes advantage of the variation of the inflection point of the emissive probe I-V characteristic with electron emission. The edge of the electron-free sheath is identified as the position where the inflection point changes from increasing with emission to decreasing with emission. (c) 2006 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ion flow and sheath physics studies in multiple ion species plasmas using diode laser based laser-induced fluorescence
z:row.Keyword: plasma sheath|plasma diagnostics|plasma spectroscopy|BOHM CRITERION|POSITIVE-ION|MULTICOMPONENT PLASMAS|ELECTRON|VELOCITY|Materials Science, Multidisciplinary|Materials Science, Coatings & Films|Physics, Applied|Physics, Condensed Matter
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ San Diego, Dept Phys, San Diego, CA 92110 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Dublin City Univ, Natl Ctr Plasma Sci & Technol, Dublin 9, Ireland. Univ Calif Irvine, Dept Phys & Astron, Irvine, CA 92049 USA.; Severn, (TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Diode lasers have proved to be a valuable light source for laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) measurements for plasma science since the early 1990s, and they have recently improved the state of the art of measuring ion flow from ion velocity distribution functions (ivdfs) at the sheath-presheath boundary in single and multiple ion species plasmas. In the case of a low temperature two ion species plasma (ArI+HeI), we were the first to show experimentally that ion species may reach the sheath edge flowing at a very different speed than that expected from the single species Bohm Criterion (ArII ions exceed the individual Bohm flow speed by almost a factor of 2 at the sheath edge). Simulation results are found to agree. Diode laser technology relevant to LIF measurements in multiple ion species plasmas is discussed with the aim of addressing outstanding problems in sheath formation in such plasmas. (c) 2005 Elsevier B.V All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: *SACH LAS TECHN IN, MOD TEC 100 0655 25 BASURTO E, 2000, PHYS REV E, V61, P3053 BATCHET G, 1993, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V5, P3097 BOHM D, 1949, CHARACTERISTICS ELEC CARRERE M, 1996, REV SCI INSTRUM, V67, P4124 FRANKLIN RN, 2000, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V33, P3186 FRANKLIN RN, 2001, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V34, P1959 GERSTENKORN S, 1993, ATLAS SPECTRE ABSORP, V2 GOECKNER MJ, 1992, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V4, P1663 GULICK SL, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V176, P1059 HALA AM, 2001, REV SCI INSTRUM, V72, P2279 HALA MA, 2000, THESIS U WISCONSIN M HAWTHORN CJ, 2001, REV SCI INSTRUM, V72, P4477 HILL DN, 1983, REV SCI INSTRUM, V54, P309 KUSHNER MJ, 1985, J APPL PHYS, V58, P4024 LANGMUIR I, 1923, GE REV, V25, P731 LANGMUIR I, 1923, SCIENCE, V57, P58 LANGMUIR I, 1929, PHYS REV, V33, P954 LEUNG KN, 1976, PHYS FLUIDS, V19, P1045 MEASSICK S, 1985, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V13, P113 MEYER JA, 1992, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V1, P147 NAKANO T, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V72, P3384 NAKANO T, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V72, P3384 OKSUZ L, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V8, P1729 OKSUZ L, 2002, PHYS REV LETT, V89 RIEMANN KU, 1991, J PHYS D, V24, P493 RIEMANN KU, 1995, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V23, P709 SEVERN GD, 1998, REV SCI INSTRUM, V69, P10 SEVERN GD, 2003, PHYS REV LETT, V90 VALENTINI HB, 1996, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V29, P1175 WENIG G, 2003, SURF COAT TECH, V174, P482; NR: 31; TC: 0; J9: THIN SOLID FILMS; PG: 5; GA: 034ME

z:row.TitlePrimary: SiO2 and Si3N4 etch mechanisms in NF3/hydrocarbon plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Machima, P, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Low-pressure inductive plasma was used to study SiO2 and Si3N4 etching with NF3/hydrocarbon chemistry. NF3 and a hydrocarbon were used so that fluorine and carbon could be supplied from feed gases other than global warming fluorocarbons. Etch rates of SiO2 are less than the Si3N4 etch rates over a wide range of conditions. With 50 W of wafer power, the SiO2 etch rate was of the order of 25 nm min(-1) while the Si3N4 etch rate was of the order of 50 nm min(-1). Similarly to a fluorocarbon chemistry, the etch process yields a very thin carbon-based steady-state film whose characteristics were determined with ex situ x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). From mass spectrometry and XPS, CHxF, CF2 and CF3 were produced but in small concentrations compared with CHx and CN. Comparisons of normalized F Is spectra of nitride and oxide show that relative concentrations of CF2 and CF3 on SiO2 are much lower than the concentrations on Si3N4. It appears that SiO2 preferentially reacts with CF2 and CF3 only but not with C-C or CH,F. Differences in the abilities of SiO2 and Si3N4 to react with C-C structures contributed to higher etch rates of Si3N4.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: *US EPA OFF ATM PR, 2002, 430R02003 US EPA OFF *US EPA, 2003, 430R03004 US EPA CLAYTON JO, 1932, J AM CHEM SOC, V54, P2610 DURRANT SF, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V71, P448 FAWCETT FS, 1964, J AM CHEM SOC, V86, P2576 HUA XF, 2003, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V21, P1708 ITO M, 2002, J APPL PHYS, V91, P3452 KAWAMURA E, 1999, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V8, P45 LAI C, 1995, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V13, P2086 LANGAN JG, 1998, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V16, P2108 LIDE DR, 1994, HDB CHEM PHYS 1913 1, P55 MOTOMURA H, 2000, THIN SOLID FILMS, V374, P243 NAKAMURA M, 2001, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V19, P2134 NAKAMURA S, 2003, JPN J APPL PHYS 1, V42, P5759 PACE EL, 1968, J CHEM PHYS, V48, P1231 PERRY WL, 2001, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V19, P2272 POSSEME N, 2003, J VAC SCI TECHNOL B, V21, P2432 PRUETTE L, 2000, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V18, P2749 SCHAEPKENS M, 1999, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V17, P26 SMYTH CP, 1934, J AM CHEM SOC, V56, P1697 SOBOLEWSKI MA, 2002, J APPL PHYS 1, V91, P6303 TANAKA J, 2000, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V18, P938 TORRES I, 2002, J PHYS B-AT MOL OPT, V35, P4113 WANI E, 2000, ELECTROCHEM SOC P, P221; NR: 24; TC: 0; J9: J PHYS-D-APPL PHYS; PG: 12; GA: 023CO

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of finite length on the current-voltage characteristic of a cylindrical Langmuir probe in a multidipole plasma chamber
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Hoskinson, AR, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; arhoskinson@wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: Cylindrical probes of finite length are shown to collect an electron current that increases more quickly with voltage than in the ideal orbital motion limited theory. For thin probes in a hot filament-enerated plasma confined by a multipole arrangement of magnets, the strength of this effect varies inversely with the probe length and is significant even for probes in excess of 50 Debye lengths long. Modelling the excess current as being collected on the end by an ideal hemispherical probe (as has been done for ion collection) fails to accurately describe the experimental data. Instead a semi-empirical power law fitting first suggested by Sudit and Woods (1994 J. Appl. Phys. 76 4488) has been used. The exponent varies strongly with both the non-dimensional probe length and the probe radius. An approximate analytical expression for this exponent is presented.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Deposition of highly hydrogenated carbon films by a modified plasma assisted chemical vapor deposition technique
z:row.Keyword: plasma CVD|hydrogenated carbon films|CONTAINING HYDROCARBON COATINGS|THERMAL-STABILITY|MECHANICAL-PROPERTIES|AMORPHOUS-CARBON|RAMAN-SPECTRA|Materials Science, Coatings & Films|Physics, Applied
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Louisiana State Univ, Dept Mech Engn, Baton Rouge, LA 70803 USA. Timken Co, Timken Res, Canton, OH 44706 USA. Case Western Reserve Univ, Dept Chem Engn, Cleveland, OH 44106 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Meng, WJ, L(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Highly hydrogenated carbon films, with hydrogen content approaching 60 at.%, were deposited with a modified, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) assisted, chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique. During deposition, flux of ionic species to the substrate surface was reduced by inserting a glass tube-grounded wire-mesh screen assembly between a CH4/Ar ICP and the substrate. Film characterization was accomplished by combining hydrogen elastic recoil detection, Raman spectroscopy, and instrumented nanoindentation. Film thermal stability was studied through high-temperature annealing in vacuum. We suggest that a decreased ratio of ionic to activated neutral species flux to the substrate during deposition is responsible for the increased hydrogen incorporation. (c) 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Sheaths: More complicated than you think
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Hershkowitz, N, Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Sheaths in low temperature collisionless and weakly collisional plasmas are often viewed as simple examples of nonlinear physics. How well do we understand them? Closer examination indicates that they are far from simple. Moreover, many predicted sheath properties have not been experimentally verified and even the appropriate "Bohm velocity" for often encountered two-ion species plasma is unknown. In addition, a variety of sheathlike structures, e.g., double layers, can exist, and many two- and three-dimensional sheath effects have not been considered. Experimental studies of sheaths and presheaths in weakly collisional plasmas are described. A key diagnostic is emissive probes operated in the "limit of zero emission." Emissive probes provide a sensitive diagnostic of plasma potential with a resolution approaching 0.1 V and a spatial resolution of 0.1 cm. Combined with planar Langmuir probes and laser-induced fluorescence, they have been used to investigate a wide variety of sheath, presheath, and sheathlike structures. Our experiments have provided some answers but have also raised more questions. (c) 2005 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma, presheath, collisional sheath and collisionless sheath potential profiles in weakly ionized, weakly collisional plasma
z:row.Keyword: LASER-INDUCED FLUORESCENCE|PATCH ACTIVE PLASMA|BOHM CRITERION|MAGNETIZED PLASMA|ION COLLECTION|PRE-SHEATH|TRANSITION|PROBES|FLOW|VELOCITIES|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Oksuz, L, Dublin City Univ, Plasma Res Lab, Dublin 9, Ireland.
z:row.Abstract: Potential variations in bulk plasma, presheath and sheath describe the plasma potential profile responsible for ion acceleration out of weakly ionized, weakly collisional plasma. Experiments with emissive probes, Langmuir probes, laser induced fluorescence (LIF) and Mach probes in a multi-dipole plasma show that the presheath potential near a negatively biased plate scales as -e phi/T-e = root(x(0)-x)/lambda and is insensitive to the value of the plate bias. Plasma parameters were chosen so that epsilon =lambda(D)/lambda approximate to 0.02 -> 0.06 and 0.2 < lambda/L < 0.6, where; is the ion-neutral mean free path, lambda(D) is the Debye length and L is the plasma length. A Child-Langmuir-like sheath with width scaling as lambda(D)(e phi/T-e)(3/4) with a T-e/lambda(D) initial boundary electric field has been measured. A transition region, in which the plasma starts to deviate from being quasi-neutral, is observed between the presheath and the Child-Langmuir sheath. The transition region is approximately 2 lambda(D) or lambda(1/5)lambda(d)(4/5). d Mach probe data, calibrated by LIF data, suggest that the average ion velocity reaches the Bohm velocity inside the transition region and significantly exceeds the Bohm velocity at the Child-Langmuir sheath/transition boundary.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Presheath environment in weakly ionized single and multispecies plasmas
z:row.Keyword: Bohm velocity|charge exchange|free fall motion|ion-ion streaming instability|ion velocity|mobility limited flow|presheath|sheath|weakly ionized plasma|LASER-INDUCED FLUORESCENCE|BOHM CRITERION|POSITIVE-ION|ELECTRON|TEMPERATURE|TRANSITION|COLLISIONS|CATHODE|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PISCATAWAY; 445 HOES LANE, PISCATAWAY, NJ 08855 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Hershkowitz, N, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; hershkowitz@engr.wic.edu
z:row.Abstract: The presheath located near boundaries in weakly ionized plasmas is a rich environment in which charge exchange, and ion-ion streaming instabilities combine to establish the electric fields that accelerate ions to close to the Bohm velocity at the sheath/presheath boundary. Charge exchange sets the presheath scale length in weakly collisional plasma, in which ionization can be neglected. The transition of mobility limited ion flow near the bulk plasma to free fall motion close to the plate for single species plasmas is explored. Measurements in argon-helium multidipole plasmas of plasma potential with emissive probes and ion energy distribution functions with laser induced fluorescence are presented. These data show that the argon ions are speeded up by the presheath electric fields, argon ions are heated, and ion-ion instability is present as ions approach the boundary.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Understanding Mach probes and Langmuir probes in a drifting, unmagnetized, non-uniform plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Oksuz, L, Suleyman Demirel Univ, Fizik Bolumu, Isparta, Turkey.; oksuz@fef.sdu.edu.tr
z:row.Abstract: The effects of non-uniform drifting plasmas (in presheaths) on planar Langmuir probes and Mach probes are investigated in an unmagnetized argon plasma. Mach probe data are compared with double-sided Langmuir probe data. The calculated plasma potential from the Langmuir probe is found to be approximately equal to the average of the plasma potentials calculated from data on each side of the Mach probe. A new method is presented to determine the ion drift velocity using the electron saturation currents for u(m) < 1 where u(m) is the Mach number. This approach has the advantage that it uses much higher currents. It is shown that a single-sided planar probe gives information about the plasma almost an ion-neutral collision length away from the probe and should not be used in drifting plasma. The one-sided Langmuir probe on the downstream side of the Mach probe indicates the plasma potential where the ion drift velocity is zero and a one-sided Langmuir probe on the upstream side of the Mach probe also indicates the plasma potential where the ion drift velocity is zero.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: CHUNG KS, 1989, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V1, P2229 CHUNG KS, 1991, J APPL PHYS, V69, P3451 CHUNG KS, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V71, P1177 FISHER ER, 2002, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V11, A105 GULICK SL, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V176, P1059 GULICK SL, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V177, P1059 HARBOUR PJ, 1984, J NUCL MATER, V121, P222 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, V1, P113 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1998, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V26, P1610 HSU SC, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 2, V8, P1916 HUDIS M, 1970, J APPL PHYS, V41, P5011 HUTCHINSON IH, 1987, PHYS FLUIDS, V30, P3777 HUTCHINSON IH, 2002, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V9, P1832 HUTCHINSON IH, 2002, PLASMA PHYS CONTR F, V44, P1953 KATO I, 2000, JPN J APPL PHYS 1, V39, P6404 KOLTAI L, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V176, P1044 KOLTAI L, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V177, P1044 LEUNG KN, 1976, PHYS FLUIDS, V19, P1045 LIPSCHULTZ B, 1986, J VAC SCI TECHNOL 2, V4, P1810 MEASSICK S, 1985, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V13, P115 OKSUZ L, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V8, P1729 OKSUZ L, 2002, PHYS REV LETT, V89 SHINOHARA S, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS, V8, P1154 SMITH HMM, 1926, PHYS REV, V28, P727 STANGEBY PC, 1984, PHYS FLUIDS, V27, P2699; NR: 25; TC: 4; J9: PLASMA SOURCES SCI TECHNOL; PG: 9; GA: 829BB

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental studies of the Bohm criterion in a two-ion-species plasma using laser-induced fluorescence
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ San Diego, Dept Phys, San Diego, CA 92110 USA.; Severn, GD, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The Bohm criterion is studied experimentally in the case of a two ion species plasma. Measurements are carried out in Ar and Ar + He plasmas (P-Ar I similar to 0.1 mtorr, 0 less than or equal to P-He/P-Ar less than or equal to 25, and 0 less than or equal to n(He)(+)/n(e) less than or equal to 0.5, T-e less than or equal to 2 eV) created in an unmagnetized dc hot filament discharge confined by surface multidipole magnetic fields. Laser-induced fluorescence (LIF) measurements of Ar II ion velocity distribution functions (ivdfs) within the presheath up to the sheath edge show that the ions reach the sheath edge traveling faster than their individual Bohm speed by more than 75%, approaching a speed equal to the ion sound speed of the system.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BASURTO E, 2000, PHYS REV E, V61, P3053 BOHM D, 1949, CHARACTERISTICS ELEC, CH3 CARRERE M, 1996, REV SCI INSTRUM, V67, P4124 FRANKLIN RN, 2000, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V33, P3186 FRANKLIN RN, 2001, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V34, P1959 GERSTENKORN S, 1993, ATLAS SPECTRE ABSORP, V2 HALA AM, 2001, REV SCI INSTRUM, V72, P2279 HALA MA, 2000, THESIS U WISCONSIN M HILL DN, 1983, REV SCI INSTRUM, V54, P309 LANGMUIR I, 1929, PHYS REV, V33, P954 LEUNG KN, 1976, PHYS FLUIDS, V19, P1045 MEASSICK S, 1985, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V13, P115 MEYER JA, 1992, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V1, P147 NAKANO T, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V72, P3384 NAKANO T, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V72, P3384 OKSUZ L, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V8, P1729 OKSUZ L, 2002, PHYS REV LETT, V89 RIEMANN KU, 1995, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V23, P709 SEVERN GD, 1998, REV SCI INSTRUM, V69, P10 SMITH JR, 1979, REV SCI INSTRUM, V50, P210 SONG SB, 1997, PHYS REV E B, V55, P1213 VALENTINI HB, 1996, J PHYS D APPL PHYS, V29, P1175; NR: 22; TC: 15; J9: PHYS REV LETT; PG: 4; GA: 668XH

z:row.TitlePrimary: First experimental measurements of the plasma potential throughout the presheath and sheath at a boundary in a weakly collisional plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53705 USA.; Oksuz, L, Suleyman Demirel Univ, Dept Phys, Isparta, Turkey.
z:row.Abstract: Experimental data obtained with emissive probes and Langmuir probes show that the plasma potential profile in the presheath scales as -ephi/T-e=root(x(0)-x)/lambda, consistent with ion flux conservation, and that the sheath consists of a transition region and an electron-free collisionless sheath with thicknesses scaling as lambda(1/5)lambda(D)(4/5) and lambda(D)(ephi/T-e)(3/4), respectively, where lambda is the ion-neutral collision length. Results support Rieman's presheath and transitional region model [Phys. Plasmas 4, 4158 (1997)]. The potential drop over the presheath and transition sheath region were the order of T-e/e and 2T(e)/3e, respectively, increasing with increasing pressure.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BISSELL RC, 1987, PHYS FLUIDS, V30, P779 BOHM D, 1949, CHARACTERISTICS ELEC CARUSO A, 1962, NUOVO CIMENTO, V26, P1389 CHEN FF, 1974, INTRO PLASMA PHYSICS EMMERT GA, 1980, PHYS FLUIDS, V23, P803 FRANKLIN RN, 1970, J PLASMA PHYS, V4, P371 FRANKLIN RN, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS, V8, P643 LEUNG KN, 1976, PHYS FLUIDS, V19, P1045 LIEBERMAN MA, 1994, PRINCIPLES PLASMA DI MEASSICK S, 1985, IEEE T PLASMA SCI, V13, P115 MEYER JA, 1992, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V1, P147 OKSUZ L, 2001, PHYS PLASMAS 1, V8, P1729 RIEMANN KU, 1981, PHYS FLUIDS, V24, P2163 RIEMANN KU, 1997, PHYS PLASMAS, V4, P4158 SELF SA, 1966, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P2486 SMITH JR, 1979, REV SCI INSTRUM, V50, P210 STANGEBY PC, 2000, PLASMA BOUNDARY MAGN TONKS L, 1929, PHYS REV, V34, P876; NR: 18; TC: 23; J9: PHYS REV LETT; PG: 3; GA: 595BP

z:row.TitlePrimary: An emissive probe with a rhenium filament for measuring plasma potential in a radio frequency oxygen plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Wilson, EH, Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Plasma potential measurements in a rf inductively coupled oxygen plasma were carried out using an emissive probe with rhenium filaments. Rhenium was chosen because of the remarkable electrical conductivity of its oxide which is 10(8) times higher than tungsten oxide. Using 75 mum diam filaments hot-wire emissive probe measurements of an oxygen plasma potential were performed in pressures of 3-100 mTorr. Due to surface contaminants, filament conditioning was performed in order to allow electron emission. Analysis of time-averaged current-voltage curves yielded the maximum and minimum of the rf fluctuation in the plasma. Axial profiles of the plasma potential fluctuations at 3.3 mTorr show a nearly linear decrease with the distance from the wall, and demonstrate the feasibility for further investigation of oxygen plasmas using rhenium filaments. (C) 2002 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ion acoustic wave velocity measurement of the concentration of two ion species in a multi-dipole plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1NO1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Hala, AM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, 1500 Engn Dr ERB, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The concentration of two species in a multi-dipole plasma was determined by measuring the ion acoustic wave group velocity and the electron temperature. The wave was launched from a grid immersed in the plasma and was detected by a Langmuir probe. Electron temperature was found separately from an I-V characteristic trace. The measurements were performed in helium/xenon and argon/xenon plasmas. Typical parameters of the plasma were T(e)similar to0.5-3 eV, density 10(10) cm(-3), plasma potential of 3-5 V, and pressure range from 1 to 20 mTorr. The accuracy of the measurement was from 2% to 4% depending on the mass difference between the two species and how accurately the group velocity and electron temperature are measured. (C) 2001 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Laser induced fluorescence of argon ions in a plasma presheath
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1NO1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Suleyman Demirel Univ, Dept Phys, Isparta, Turkey. Cairo Univ, Laser Inst, Giza, Egypt.; Oksuz, L, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The characteristics of presheaths near an electrically floating plate in weakly collisional argon multidipole plasmas are investigated with a combination of data from laser induced fluorescence using a diode laser, Mach probes, emissive probes, and Langmuir probes. It is shown that ion-neutral collisions result in an increase in ion temperature from approximately room temperature in the bulk plasma to 0.13 eV, 0.5 cm from the plate, the location of the closest measurement. In addition, at that point, the presheath plasma potential drop is greater than T-e/2, and the drift velocity is equal to 0.5 c(s), where c(s) is the ion sound velocity. (C) 2001 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design and operation of an Omegatron mass spectrometer for measurements of positive and negative ion species in electron cyclotron resonance plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Hanyang Univ, Dept Phys, Ansan 425791, South Korea.; Koo, BW, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The Omegatron mass spectrometer, originally developed for measuring atomic constants, was employed for measuring both positive ions and negative ions in high density, electron cyclotron resonance etching plasmas. The main disadvantages of the conventional design of the Omegatron include the observation of resonance frequency shifts and poor mass resolution in a relatively weak magnetic field. Based on 2D numerical analysis, several modifications were carried out to overcome these limitations: the (+/-) ion collector, differential pumping, different RF excitation methods, an additional magnet for uniform magnetic field, etc. Experimental results indicated the presence of H- and H-2(-) in H-2 plasmas, and F- and CF- in CF4 plasmas.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Asymmetric plasma potential fluctuation in an inductive plasma source
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Lho, T, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Time-averaged plasma potential in an inductive source with a ground wall has been measured by using an emissive probe. The inflection point method in the limit of zero emission is employed to determine the plasma potential. In this source, capacitive coupling results in a fluctuating plasma potential. The peak-to-peak value of the radiofrequency (RF) fluctuations, which is approximately given by the separation of the two peaks in the derivative of an I-V characteristic curve, has been reduced by introducing a gap between the antenna and the quartz window and by various electrostatic screens. Experimental data show that the lower potential peak, representing the lowest plasma potential, was approximately constant as the RF fluctuation level was reduced, while the higher potential peak, indicating the more positive plasma potential, changed and approached the lower potential peak. For very low fluctuation level, the lower potential peak becomes the de plasma potential and only the higher potential peak responds to the RF fluctuation.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of harmonic rf fields on the emissive probe characteristics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Lho, T, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: New features of the emissive probe characteristic curves in an inductive plasma source were observed in the E mode operation. More than the two inflection points in the derivative of the I-V characteristic curves are found when the harmonics of the input frequency (13.56 MHz) are present. The pairs of inflection points are symmetric about dc plasma potential. (C) 2000 American Institute of Physics. [S0034-6748(00)02702-7].

z:row.TitlePrimary: Langmuir probe in low temperature, magnetized plasmas: Theory and experimental verification
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Appl Mat Inc, Santa Clara, CA 95054 USA.; Koo, BW, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Langmuir probe theory, adapted to magnetized, partially ionized, low temperature processing plasmas with radial diffusion dominated by electron-neutral collisions, was verified in electron cyclotron resonance (ECR) plasmas. Plasma parameters such as plasma potential, electron temperature, plasma density, and the ratio of electron saturation current to ion saturation current (I-e*/I-i*) were measured by single-sided planar probe in various ECR plasmas (H-2, He, N-2,O-2, Ar, and CF4). The neutral pressure was varied between 0.5 and 8.5 mTorr and the microwave power between 170 and 1250 W with good matching conditions; the reflected power was kept at less than 3% of the input power. The measured ratios of I-e*/I-i*, and other plasma parameters were consistent with the probe theory for pressures greater than 2.0 mTorr for various plasmas of Ar, He, H-2, and N-2. These results indicate that the electron-neutral collisional probe theory works well for magnetized ECR plasmas (magnetic flux densities of 0.8-1.0 kG). (C) 1999 American Institute of Physics. [S0021-8979(99)06815-2].
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BISSELL RC, 1987, PHYS FLUIDS, V30, P779 BROWN SC, 1994, BASIC DATA PLASMA PH, P1 CHAPMAN B, 1980, GLOW DISCHARGE PROCE, P21 CHEN FF, 1984, INTRO PLASMA PHYSICS CHRISTOPHOROU LG, 1996, J PHYS CHEM REF DATA, V25, P1341 EMMERT GA, 1980, PHYS FLUIDS, V23, P803 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, V1, P113 HUTCHINSON IH, 1987, PRINCIPLES PLASMA DI KIM GH, 1994, 47 ANN GAS EL C SASAKI K, 1996, INT C PLASM SCI BOST STANGEBY PC, 1982, J PHYS D, V15, P1007 STANGEBY PC, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, P113 STANOJEVIC M, 1993, CONTRIB PLASM PHYS, V33, P241 STANOJEVIC M, 1994, CONTRIB PLASM PHYS, V34, P607 STEVENS JE, 1992, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V10, P1270; NR: 15; TC: 14; J9: J APPL PHYS; PG: 8; GA: 216TD

z:row.TitlePrimary: Launched wave packets in an ion beam-plasma system
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Korea Basic Sci Inst, Taejon, South Korea. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Nucl Engn & Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Lee, SG, Korea Basic Sci Inst, Taejon, South Korea.
z:row.Abstract: A generation mechanism of wave packets and measurement of the launched wave packets using Langmuir probes in an ion beam-plasma system are presented. The origin of the wave packets appears to be the Johnson noise of a resistor in a simple amplifying circuit. The measured wave packets were found to propagate on the slow beam mode. z:row.TitlePrimary: Role of plasma-aided manufacturing in semiconductor fabrication
z:row.Keyword: CYCLOTRON-RESONANCE PLASMA|INDUCTIVELY-COUPLED PLASMA|SOURCE|ION-IMPLANTATION|MODULATED HIGH-DENSITY|SURFACE MODIFICATION|NEGATIVE-IONS|MOORES LAW|DISCHARGES|CHLORINE|ENERGY|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Hershkowitz, N, Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; hershkowitz@engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: A brief review is presented of the application of plasma-aided manufacturing to semiconductor fabrication. Emphasis is placed on current state-of-the-art techniques for which plasma physics plays a significant role and on current problems that remain to be solved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Real-time determination of plasma etch-rate selectivity
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Real-time etch-rate selectivity of thin transparent films is determined within seconds by an in situ two-colour laser interferometer. Two-point laser reflectrometry is used to determine the etch rates and etch selectivity of unpatterned polysilicon and SiO2 films. The state of a magnetically confined inductively coupled plasma tool used in the experiments, including rf power to the antenna and the wafer stage, gas pressure and flow rates, is computer controlled and monitored. The dependence of the etch selectivity on tool state parameters is characterized in real time by varying the tool state and monitoring the etch rate of the films. The etch rate measurements have been combined with density characterization of the etch radicals in the discharge. The time-dependent density of atomic chlorine during the process is obtained by temporal optical-emission actinometry combined with in-line mass spectrometry from a pressure calibrated residual gas analyser. The etch selectivity of polysilicon to SiO2 in a chlorine discharge, determined by a simultaneous etch of both films, differs from the etch-rate ratios of the films when they are etched separately. It is suggested that this difference is due to the presence of oxygen in the polysilicon etch process when the two films are etched simultaneously.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Real-time monitoring and control of plasma etching
z:row.Keyword: in-situ laser interferometer|real-time etch rate monitoring|endpoint prediction|etch rate model|model-based real-time etch rate control|SIO2|Physics, Applied
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics Part 1-Regular Papers Short Notes & Review Papers
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MINATO-KU TOKYO; DAINI TOYOKAIJI BLDG 24-8 SHINBASHI 4-CHOME, MINATO-KU TOKYO, 105, JAPAN
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Sarfaty, M, Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Real-time etch rate of thin transparent films is determined within seconds by an in-situ two-color laser interferometer. The use of two colors improves the accuracy of the calculated rates, provides an absolute measure of film thickness for endpoint prediction, and differentiates between etching and deposition. The tool state parameters, rf power to the antenna and the wafer stage, gas pressure and flow rates, are computer controlled and monitored. Real-time etch rate characterization is obtained by monitoring the etch dependence on varying tool state parameters. The density of the etch radicals, chlorine and fluorine. is obtained with xenon and argon actinometry using optical emission and mass spectra. An etch rate model, based on the input power to the wafer stage and the relative density of the etch radicals, is used to develop a model-based real-time control algorithm. This algorithm has been used to control the etch rate of unpatterned polysilicon and SiO2.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A novel electro-optical probe to diagnose plasma uniformity
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Sarfaty, M, Appl Mat Inc, Santa Clara, CA 95054 USA.
z:row.Abstract: A novel electro-optical probe (EOP) has been developed to characterize the spatial uniformity of various plasma parameters. Spatially resolved electron density and energy distribution function, neutral and charged particle densities, as well as ion flow velocity are determined by the EOP. The design of the EOP combines a Mach probe, back-to-back charge collectors, and a collimated optical fiber. The light collection angle of the optical fiber is limited by recessing the fiber in a ceramic tube. The line-of-sight integration length of the plasma emission is bounded by the charge collector disk. A spatial resolution of 2.4 cm is obtained by the present design of the EOP. The ion flow velocity perpendicular to the charge collector surface is determined by the ratio of the ion saturation currents of the two counter facing charge collectors. Localized actinometry, that combines spatially resolved optical emission spectra and electron energy distribution functions, is used to determine the density of atomic chlorine and fluorine radicals. The spatial distribution is obtained by scanning the EOP across the plasma volume. (C) 1998 American Institute of Physics. [S0034-6748(98)03609-0]

z:row.TitlePrimary: Azimuthally symmetric pseudosurface and helicon wave propagation in an inductively coupled plasma at low magnetic field
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53705 USA.; Lho, T, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53705 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The mode transition from a capacitively coupled mode (E mode) to an inductively coupled mode (H mode) was observed in an inductive Ar plasma source by applying an axially uniform low B field. The applied fundamental rf was 13.56 MHz and many harmonic components were observed. A beat and standing wave patterns of azimuthally symmetric (m=0 mode) first and second harmonic pseudosurfaces and helicon waves were measured at various densities (n similar to 9.0 x 10(10)-2.2 x 10(11) cm(-3)) and B fields (12-28 G). Wave propagation mode changes, from pseudosurface to helicon waves and from helicon to pseudosurface waves, were observed at critical conditions, omega(c)/omega>3.0 and n similar to 2.2 x 10(11) cm(-3). (C) 1998 American Institute of Physics. [S1070-664X(98)02708-6].

z:row.TitlePrimary: Neutral pumping in a helicon discharge
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL BS1 6BE, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Gilland, J, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: At powers of 500-800 W of 13.56 MHz rf power in a 1 kG axial magnetic field, the neutral pressure in the bulk of a helicon discharge with electron densities of similar to 10(13) cm(-3) and electron temperatures of similar to 3 eV in argon decreased by a factor of ten compared to the pressure before the discharge. These experimental results are compared with a simple axial diffusion model of ionization and neutral transport and agree qualitatively with calculated axial profiles of neutral pressure. The effects of cusped fields on neutral density profiles and plasma confinement are also examined.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Multiple electron beams generated by a helicon plasma discharge
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Chen, RTS, Univ Wisconsin, Engn Res Ctr Plasma Aided Mfg, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Simultaneous electron beams with different energies were directly detected by Langmuir probes in a steady state helicon plasma discharge. The probe-detected electron-beam velocities were in good agreement with the phase velocities of the multimode helicon waves.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Edge-plasma trapping induced by ICRH in an end cell of a tandem mirror
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; DIRAC HOUSE, TEMPLE BACK, BRISTOL, ENGLAND BS1 6BE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: We present experimental evidence for the ion cyclotron resonant-heating (ICRH) induced trapping of ions in the edge-mirror fields of a magnetically confined plasma. Relative changes in edge-plasma density have been monitored in an end cell of the Phaedrus-B Tandem Mirror (Breun R A er al 1981 Phys. Rev. Lett. 47 1833-6; Ferron J R et al 1983 Phys. Rev. Lett. 51 1955) via the use of electron cyclotron emission from a hot-edge population created by the application of electron cyclotron resonant heating. Edge-plasma density dependence upon the ICRH left-circularly-polarized electric field (E+) and on the edge-neutral density were found to be consistent with an edge rf-trapping model. A linear correlation is observed between the change in trapped edge density and the change in the applied ICRH E+. Furthermore, if is demonstrated that cold (less than 7 eV) ions born from atomic processes operating at or near the plasma edge are the dominant species participating in the trapping process. The results obtained are shown to be applicable to any device with mirror-like closed particle orbits at the plasma edge.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Rf generated voltage on the Faraday screen of an ICRF antenna and its effect on the Phaedrus-T edge plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: VIENNA; WAGRAMERSTRASSE 5, PO BOX 100, A-1400 VIENNA, AUSTRIA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,MADISON,WI.
z:row.Abstract: Work done on the Phaedrus-T tokamak is summarized regarding RF voltages induced on the sides of slotted side Faraday screens (FSs). Direct in-air measurements show voltages induced on slotted side FSs, while theory and computer simulations suggest that these voltages are induced by radial currents on antenna feeds. Triple probe measurements In the edge region of the Phaedrus-T tokamak suggest that the induced voltages modify edge plasma parameters and increase sheath potentials, which increase sputtering of the FS material and result in an increase of the impurity content of the plasma. These effects of the induced voltages can be eliminated by using insulating plates as FS side limiters.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Magnetic-field-enhanced rf argon plasma for ionized sputtering of copper
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wang, W, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A multipole magnetic field was used to increase the ion density of an inductively coupled rf (13.5 MHZ) argon plasma for ionized magnetron sputtering of copper (Cu). Langmuir probe measurements showed an increase of plasma density over a factor of 2 with the application of the magnetic field. At an argon pressure of 15 mTorr and a rf power of 600 W, an ion density of 1.2 x 10(12) ions/cm(3) was achieved. When this plasma was applied to ionize the magnetron sputtered Cu vapor, a high emission intensity ratio from the Cu+ ion line to the Cu neutral line was observed from the optical emission spectroscopy, suggesting a high ionization fraction for the sputtered Cu vapor. (C) 1997 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: GORBATKIN SM, 1996, J VAC SCI TECHNOL B, V14, P1853 HOLBER WM, 1993, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V11, P2903 HOPWOOD J, 1995, J APPL PHYS, V78, P759 LEUNG KN, 1976, PHYS LETT A, V57, P145 LIEBERMAN MA, 1994, PRINCIPLES PLASMA DI, P146 MURARKA SP, 1993, METALLIZATION THEORY, P9 RHOADES RL, 1996, J APPL PHYS, V80, P2605 ROSSNAGEL SM, 1993, APPL PHYS LETT, V63, P3285 ROSSNAGEL SM, 1995, J VAC SCI TECHNOL B, V13, P125 WANG SQ, 1994, MRS BULL, V19, P30; NR: 10; TC: 5; J9: APPL PHYS LETT; PG: 3; GA: XW907

z:row.TitlePrimary: Edge power deposition reduction in a Tokamak by replacing the Faraday screen on an RF antenna with an insulator
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: VIENNA; WAGRAMERSTRASSE 5, PO BOX 100, A-1400 VIENNA, AUSTRIA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Sorensen, J, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Calculations show that the power coupled to the regions around the RF antenna (side, front and interior) due to the edge plasma interaction with voltages induced on the antenna structure of the Phaedrus-T tokamak was reduced from nearly 11 kW to a few hundred watts for 40 kW of RF input power by replacing the Faraday screen (FS) surrounding the antenna with insulating boron nitride (BN) side limiters. When an FS was on the antenna, calculations show that 7.7 kW of the power coupled to the edge was transferred to the electrons that passed through a potential gradient while crossing field lines and 3 kW was dissipated by ions falling through an increased sheath at the carbon limiter and FS. Experimental data of edge plasma parameters, loading resistance and intensity of VUV impurity Light support the conclusion that less power was deposited in the edge plasma when the antenna had only BN side limiters than when it was covered with an FS.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BUTLER HS, 1963, PHYS FLUIDS, V6, P1346 DIEBOLD DA, 1992, NUCL FUSION, V32, P2040 FUCHS G, 1980, NUCL FUSION, V20, P1247 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, V1, P113 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1992, 1992 INT C PLASM C 2, V16, P839 IVANOV VM, 1981, INORG MATER+, V17, P1203 MAJESKI R, 1991, AIP C P, V244, P322 MAJESKI R, 1994, FUSION ENG DES, V24, P159 MESSIAEN AM, 1994, NUCL FUSION, V34, P825 MOYER RA, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V176, P293 NOTERDAEME JM, 1993, PLASMA PHYS, V35, P1481 SORENSEN J, 1993, NUCL FUSION, V33, P915 STANGEBY PC, 1982, J PHYS D, V15, P1007 TANAKA T, 1993, THESIS U WISCONSIN M VANNIEUWENHOVE R, 1991, NUCL FUSION, V31, P1770 VANNIEUWENHOVE R, 1992, NUCL FUSION, V32, P1913 VANNIEUWENHOVE R, 1992, PLASMA PHYS, V34, P525 VANNIEUWENHOVE R, 1992, RF HEATING CURRENT E, V16, P137 VANNIEUWENHOVE R, 1994, CONTROLLED FUSIO B 2, V18, P798 VANOOST G, 1993, CONTROLLED FUSION C, V17, P671 WANG EY, 1995, NUCL FUSION, V35, P467; NR: 21; TC: 1; J9: NUCL FUSION; PG: 18; GA: XV316

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements on rotating ion cyclotron range of frequencies induced particle fluxes in axisymmetric mirror plasmas
z:row.Keyword: RADIAL POTENTIAL PROFILE|TANDEM MIRROR|INTERCHANGE STABILIZATION|TRAVELING WAVES|TRANSPORT|FIELDS|DRIFTS|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Hatakeyama, R, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A comparison of phenomenological features of plasmas is made with a special emphasis on radio-frequency induced transport, which are maintained when a set of two closely spaced dual half-turn antennas in a central cell of the Phaedrus-B axisymmetric tandem mirror [J. J. Browning et al., Phys. Fluids B 1, 1692 (1984)] is phased to excite electromagnetic fields in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies (ICRF) with m = -1 (rotating with ions) and m = +1 (rotating with electrons) azimuthal modes. Positive and negative electric currents are measured to flow axially to the end walls in the cases of m = -1 and m = +1 excitations, respectively. These parallel nonambipolar ion and electron fluxes are observed to be accompanied by azimuthal ion flows in the same directions as the antenna-excitation modes m. The phenomena are argued in terms of radial particle fluxes due to a nonambipolar transport mechanism [Hojo and Hatori, J. Phys. Sec. Jpn. 60, 2510 (1991); Hatakeyama et al., J, Phys. Sec. Jpn. 60, 2815 (1991), and Phys. Rev. E 52, 6664(1995)], which are induced when azimuthally traveling ICRF waves are absorbed in the magnetized plasma column. (C) 1997 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BERS A, 1975, PLASMA PHYSICS HOUCH, P126 BREUN RA, 1989, PLASMA PHYS CONTROLL, V2, P475 BROWNING JJ, 1988, PHYS FLUIDS, V31, P714 BROWNING JJ, 1989, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V1, P1692 CHUNG KS, 1989, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V1, P2229 DEMIRKHANOV RA, 1981, JETP LETT, V33, P28 DIMONTE G, 1988, PHYS REV LETT, V60, P1390 DOLGOPOLOV VV, 1979, SOV J PLASMA PHYS, V5, P672 FERRON JR, 1983, PHYS REV LETT, V51, P1955 FERRON JR, 1987, PHYS FLUIDS, V30, P1869 HATAKEYAMA R, 1989, 44 ANN M PHYS SOC JA, P120 HATAKEYAMA R, 1991, J PHYS SOC JPN, V60, P2815 HATAKEYAMA R, 1995, PHYS REV E B, V52, P6664 HATORI T, 1994, COMMUNICATION HOJO H, 1991, J PHYS SOC JPN, V60, P2510 HOOPER EB, 1985, PHYS FLUIDS, V28, P3609 HORTON W, 1980, NUCL FUSION, V20, P321 INOUE S, 1981, PLASMA PHYS CONTROLL, V2, P649 INUTAKE M, 1985, PHYS REV LETT, V55, P939 INUTAKE M, 1990, COMMUNICATION KLIMA R, 1973, PLASMA PHYS, V15, P1031 KONDOH T, 1994, PHYS PLASMAS, V1, P1489 MACLATCHY CS, 1992, REV SCI INSTRUM, V63, P3923 MCVEY B, ICRF ANTENNA COUPLIN MINENKO VP, 1985, SOV J PLASMA PHYS, V11, P85 NEMOV VV, 1978, SOV J PLASMA PHYS, V4, P714 OKAMURA S, 1986, NUCL FUSION, V26, P1491 RIYOPOULOS S, 1986, NUCL FUSION, V26, P627 ROSENBERG M, 1985, PHYS FLUIDS, V28, P538 SATO NY, 1994, P 1994 INT C PLASM P, V3, P221 SEGAL D, 1975, PHYS FLUIDS, V18, P640 TSUSHIMA A, 1986, PHYS REV LETT, V56, P1815 TSUSHIMA A, 1991, J PHYS SOC JPN, V60, P2665 WATARI T, 1982, NUCL FUSION, V22, P1359 WUKITCH S, 1996, PHYS REV LETT, V77, P294 YASAKA Y, 1980, PHYS REV LETT, V44, P1763 YASAKA Y, 1986, PHYS REV LETT, V56, P2811; NR: 37; TC: 6; J9: PHYS PLASMAS; PG: 8; GA: XP709

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma-parameter dependence of thin-oxide damage from wafer charging during electron-cyclotron-resonance plasma processing
z:row.Keyword: GATE OXIDES|BREAKDOWN|POLYSILICON|DEPOSITION|Engineering, Manufacturing|Engineering, Electrical & Electronic|Physics, Applied|Physics, Condensed Matter
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706. STANFORD UNIV,CTR INTEGRATED SYST,STANFORD,CA 94305.; Friedmann, JB, TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC,SEMICOND GRP,DALLAS,TX 75243.
z:row.Abstract: In this work, the effects of plasma-parameter variations on charging damage to polysilicon-gate MOS capacitor test structures exposed to O-2 electron-cyclotron-resonance (ECR) plasmas are investigated. Results will show that charging damage is generated when large potential differences exist across the gate-oxide layers of the MOS capacitor test structures and that these potential differences can only occur in the presence of plasma nonuniformities. These results demonstrate the critical need for plasma uniformity during processing, in particular as device dimensions shrink and gate-oxide thicknesses decrease, The plasma parameters were varied by adjusting the neutral gas pressure and by independently biasing a circular grid and a ring electrode located above the wafer, The damage induced in the test wafers during the plasma exposure was characterized with ramp-voltage breakdown measurements. Radial profiles of the floating potential measured with a Langmuir probe were found to vary nonuniformly when the grid electrode was positively biased due to preferential depletion of electrons relative to ions beneath the grid electrode, An equivalent-circuit model of the test wafer and the wafer-stage electrode predicts that the silicon substrate acquires a potential equal to the average of the wafer surface potential, Comparisons of the calculated profiles of the potential difference across the gate-oxide layers of the test structures and whole-wafer maps of the breakdown-voltage measurements show that the majority of the damage occurs where the oxide potential difference is largest and that the damage only occurs in the presence of plasma nonuniformities.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: APTE PP, 1993, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V140, P770 ASMUSSEN J, 1989, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V7, P883 BOX GEP, 1978, STATISTICS EXPT CHAPMAN B, 1980, GLOW DISCHARGE PROCE FANG S, 1992, IEEE ELECTR DEVICE L, V13, P347 FANG SC, 1992, IEEE ELECTR DEVICE L, V13, P288 FANG SC, 1992, J APPL PHYS, V72, P4865 FANG SC, 1994, IEEE T ELECTRON DEV, V41, P1848 FOWLER RH, 1928, P R SOC LOND A-CONTA, V119, P173 FRIEDMANN JB, 1993, J VAC SCI TECHNOL 1, V11, P1145 FRIEDMANN JB, 1995, THESIS U WISCONSIN M GABRIEL CT, 1991, J VAC SCI TECHNOL B, V9, P370 GREENE WM, 1991, J VAC SCI TECHNOL B, V9, P366 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, V1, P113 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1992, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V1, P87 HOLBER WM, 1993, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V11, P2903 KIRMSE KK, COMMUNICATION KUBOTA M, 1991, IEDM, P891 LIEBERMAN MA, 1993, ADV RES DEV, V17 NAMURA T, 1989, 11TH P S DRY PROC, P74 NAMURA T, 1990, JPN J APPL PHYS, V29, P251 PEARTON SJ, 1994, J VAC SCI TECHNOL B, V12, P1333 POPOV OA, 1994, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V12, P300 SAMUKAWA S, 1990, JPN J APPL PHYS 1, V29, P980 SAMUKAWA S, 1991, JPN J APPL PHYS PT 2, V30, L1902 SHIN H, 1993, IEEE ELECTR DEVICE L, V14, P509 SINGER P, 1993, SEMICOND INT, V16, P40 STRANGEBY PC, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, V2, P157 WU IW, 1989, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V136, P1638; NR: 29; TC: 7; J9: IEEE TRANS SEMICONDUCT MANUF; PG: 13; GA: WG842

z:row.TitlePrimary: Diagnostics for plasma processing (etching plasmas) (invited)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Hershkowitz, N, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Plasma processing diagnostics play two different roles-characterization and control. The goal of plasma characterization is to establish connections of data with external parameters and to verify models. The goal of control diagnostics is to make noninvasive in situ measurements of relevant processing parameters. Diagnostics used in semiconductor etching are considered. These include Langmuir probes, laser induced fluorescence, optical emission spectroscopy, infrared and Fourier transform infrared absorption spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, microwave interferometry, and radio frequency diagnostics. An example is given of the use of many diagnostics in characterizing SiO2 and Si etching by fluorocarbons. (C) 1997 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Use of emissive probes in high pressure plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Yan, SL, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: The characteristics of emissive probes in unmagnetized high pressure (less than or equal to 1 Torr) argon and helium plasmas, produced by inductively coupled 13.56 MHz rf power, are studied. A procedure is given for interpreting emissive probe current-voltage (I-V) characteristics. The I-V curves indicate the amplitude of the rf fluctuation of the plasma potential. They also show ionization near the emissive probe when the potential drop between the emissive probe and the plasma potential is more than the ionization potential. Experiments show that when the temperature of the emissive probe wire and/or the neutral pressure is increased, ionization becomes significant. An increase in the local ion density due to the additional ionization was demonstrated by the I-V curves of an emissive probe and a nearby Langmuir probe. A simple procedure is presented for interpreting these results. (C) 1996 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: CHAPMAN B, 1980, GLOW DISCHARGE PROCE CHEN FF, 1956, PLASMA DIAGNOSTIC TE, P113 CHEN FF, 1984, INTRO PLASMA PHYSICS CHO MH, 1988, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V6, P2978 FOREST C, 1986, J APPL PHYS, V60, P1295 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1983, REV SCI INSTRUM, V54, P29 HERSHKOWITZ N, 1989, PLASMA DIAGNOSTICS, V1, P113 KEMP RF, 1966, REV SCI INSTRUM, V37, P455 LIZUKA S, 1981, J PHYS E, V14, P1291 OKUNO Y, 1991, J APPL PHYS, V70, P642 OKUNO Y, 1994, PHYS LETT A, V193, P94 PENNEBAKER WB, 1979, IBM J RES DEV, V23, P16 SMITH JR, 1979, REV SCI INSTRUM, V50, P210 WANG EY, 1985, REV SCI INSTRUM, V56, P519 WANG EY, 1986, REV SCI INSTRUM, V57, P2425 YAMADA H, 1970, PHYS FLUIDS, V14, P1120; NR: 16; TC: 4; J9: REV SCI INSTR; PG: 8; GA: WA091

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wide solitons in an ion-beam-plasma system
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lee, SG, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Solitons are experimentally found in a double plasma device when an ion beam is present with beam velocity vb in the range 1 less than or equal to nu(b)/c(s) less than or equal to 2.2, where c(s) is the ion acoustic velocity. These one dimensional solitons have an unusually large width (parallel to the direction of propagation) W approximate to 14 lambda(D)(delta n/n)(-1/2), where lambda(D) is the Debye length and delta n/n is the maximum normalized density fluctuation. The amplitude, width, and velocity characteristics of the solitons are found to be in good agreement with the soliton solution to the Korteweg-de Vries equation in an ion-beam-plasma system.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental observation of rf driven plasma flow in the phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: We have observed frequency shifts of the 2/1 tearing mode in a tokamak that are consistent with injecting momentum with low frequency rf waves. The 2/1 frequency increased for current drive antenna phasing, decreased for anticurrent drive phasing, and was linear with rf power and driven current. The change in the toroidal velocities derived from the frequency shifts and the calculated rf momentum is consistent. The frequency change also increased with magnetic field, independent of antenna phasing. This is the first demonstration of modifying the 2/1 frequency through rf momentum input.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Etch rate and plasma density radial uniformity measurements in a cusped field helicon plasma etcher
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A-Vacuum Surfaces and Films
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Quick, AK, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Experiments on the University of Wisconsin helicon etcher were conducted to study the effects on uniformity of applying a cusped magnetic field to the etching chamber. Also a comparison was made between long and short antenna/substrate separation distances. The plasma radial density uniformities, measured using a Langmuir probe over the inner 10 cm diameter of the chamber, gave maximum density variations of +/- 22% with the cusp off and +/- 1.28% at the zero field region of the cusp. The maximum SiO2 etch rate in CF4/Ar plasmas occurred at 50% Ar concentration in the long source configuration. Etch rate uniformity of SiO2 etching in a CF4/Ar/O-2 plasma improved from +/- 8.1% to +/- 2.6% for a 82.5 mm wafer by shortening the antenna-substrate separation distance from 108 to 47 cm. Azimuthal asymmetry of the plasma produced from the Nagoya type III antenna was observed in the shea source configuration in which the SiO2 etch rate uniformity varied from +/- 1.5% across the vertical axis of a 150-mm-diam wafer to +/- 12% across the horizontal axis of the wafer. (C) 1996 American Vacuum Society.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Does high density low pressure etching depend on the type of plasma source?
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Hershkowitz, N, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Etching of SiO2 with CF4 in three types of high density-low pressure (5X10(11) cm(-3), 1-10 mTorr) etch tools: electron cyclotron resonance (ECR), inductively coupled (ICP), and helicon (HRF) is described. Although the physical processes that produce the plasma in the three types of sources are quite different, the etch rate processes are identical when viewed from the wafer sheath boundary. Measurements demonstrate that if sufficient fluorine is present, the etch rate limiting step depends only on the ion energy flux to the wafer, rather than on the details of the chemical species. Etch rate control depends only on the wafer bias power. Experimental results are device independent so the etch rate in high density-low pressure plasma sources does not depend on the plasma source power. Major differences in tool etch rate characteristics are more likely determined by tool wall material (and wall chemistry) and tool geometry rather than the physical process that is used to produce the plasma. (C) 1996 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: DING J, 1993, J VAC SCI TECHNOL 1, V11, P1283 DING J, 1996, APPL PHYS LETT, V68, P1619 JENQ JS, 1994, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V3, P154 KIM GH, 1995, PHYS PLASMAS, V2, P3222 LIEBERMAN MA, 1994, PRINCIPLES PLASMA DI MANOS DA, 1989, PLASMA ETCHING INTRO MEYER JA, 1992, PLASMA SOURCES SCI T, V1, P147; NR: 7; TC: 5; J9: PHYS PLASMAS; PN: Part 2; PG: 6; GA: UK938

z:row.TitlePrimary: Alfven ion-ion hybrid wave heating in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Intrator, T, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: In the Phaedrus-T tokamak [R. A. Breun et al., Fusion Technol. 19, 1327 (1991)], Alfven waves are indirectly driven by a fast wave antenna array. Small fractions of minority ions are shown to have a large effect on the Alfven spectrum, as measured at the edge. An ion-ion hybrid Alfven mode has been identified by measuring dispersion properties. Landau damping is predicted to be large and spatially localized. These Alfvenic waves are experimentally shown to generate correlated electron heating and changes in density near the core of the tokamak plasma. Fast wave antenna fields can mode convert at a hybrid Alfven resonance and provide a promising route to spatially localized tokamak heating and current drive, even for low effective ionic charge Z(eff)approximate to 1.3-2. (C) 1996 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Symmetric rate model for fluorocarbon plasma etching of SiO2
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A symmetric rate model for plasma etching and plasma deposition in fluorocarbon plasmas is proposed. When there is no deposition, the symmetric rate model gives a plasma etch rate. When there is no etching, the model gives a plasma deposition rate. Electron cyclotron resonance and reactive ion etcher etch rates of SiO2 in CF4 plasma are found to be consistent with the model. (C) 1996 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: LITWIN, C, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: The loop voltage response in the low-frequency current drive experiments is analyzed in order to extract information about the current drive profile and efficiency. (C) 1995 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental Studies of Multimode Helicon Plasma-Waves
z:row.Keyword: INDUCTIVELY COUPLED PLASMA|LOWER HYBRID FREQUENCY|RADIO-FREQUENCY|WHISTLER WAVES|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BRISTOL; TECHNO HOUSE, REDCLIFFE WAY, BRISTOL, ENGLAND BS1 6NX
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, RTS, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Helicon waves were excited by a Nagoya type III antenna in a steady state argon magnetized plasma column with Dc magnetic field B-o = 400-500 G, electron density 10(12)-10(13) cm(-3) and neutral species pressure about 20 mTorr. Wavelength measurements made with B-dot probes at the edge of the plasma column show the presence of multimode standing helicon waves. Azimuthal mode numbers m = +1, 0 and -1 were detected with m = +1 dominant. Radial density profiles were measured with Langmuir probes. The wavelength measurements are shown to agree with theoretical calculations of helicon waves in radially non-uniform plasma.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A 2-Dimensional Particle-In-Cell Simulation of an Electron-Cyclotron-Resonance Etching Tool
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: ASHTIANI, KA, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A particle-in-cell (PIG) simulation of an axisymmetric electron-cyclotron-resonance (ECR) etching tool is developed in which up to 2x10(6) particles per species are loaded in a two-dimensional spatial computational mesh (r,z), along with three velocity components (upsilon(r),upsilon(theta),upsilon(z)). An ECR heating scheme based on single-particle trajectories in the resonance zone generates the simulated plasma. Electron- and ion-neutral elastic and inelastic collisions are treated by a null. Monte Carlo collision method. The code generates the electron and ion-velocity distributions, plasma potentials, and densities in a CF3+/CF4 etching plasma. In addition, a novel scaling technique which bridges the gap between the ion and electron-time scales and accelerates the rate of convergence of the code is introduced for a PIC code. The predictions of the code show that microwaves are completely absorbed before reaching the exact location of resonance. (C) I995 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Magnetic and Collisional Effects on Presheaths
z:row.Keyword: HELMHOLTZ VORTEX FORMATION|FIELD PLASMA SHEATH|PARTICLE-TRANSPORT|ELECTRIC SHEATH|TRANSITION|CRITERION|SURFACE|PROBE|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706. UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: The effects of both magnetic field and collisions on presheath properties are experimentally investigated in plasmas with electron temperatures much greater than ion temperatures. Measurements of plasma potential in collisionless plasmas show presheath thicknesses at boundaries oblique to magnetic field to be approximately (C-s/omega(ci))sin psi where C-s is the ion sound speed, omega(ci) is the ion gyrofrequency, and Psi is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the wall boundary. Measurements of plasma potential in collisional plasmas find presheaths consisting of two distinctive regions. With ion-neutral collision mean-free path lambda(n)<(C-s/omega(ci))sin psi the presheath region next to the sheath has collisional characteristics and a thickness of approximately (0.5-0.6)lambda(n). The corresponding presheath region adjacent to the bulk plasma has magnetic characteristics and a thickness of approximately (0.5-0.9)(C-s/omega(ci)sin psi. Equipotential contours in the collisional region of this presheath are found to be parallel to the boundary, while those in the magnetic region are not. (C) 1995 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Biased H-Mode Experiments in Phaedrus-T
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: VIENNA; WAGRAMERSTRASSE 5 PO BOX 100, A-1400 VIENNA, AUSTRIA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SW INST PHYS,SICHUAN 610041,PEOPLES R CHINA. JOHNS HOPKINS UNIV,DEPT PHYS & ASTRON,BALTIMORE,MD 21218.; WANG, EY, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Inserting a positively biased electrode to just inside the Phaedrus-T tokamak limiter results in typical H mode behaviour (i.e. H-alpha or D-alpha drop, density rise, increase in stored energy, profile steepening, and reduction of edge turbulence and radial transport) in deuterium, hydrogen and helium discharges. H-alpha or D-alpha emission suggests that the improvement in particle confinement with H mode is poloidally asymmetric, with the greatest improvement occurring on the low field side. The radial conductivity is examined and measured values are compared with theory.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: ASKINAZI LG, 1992, NUCL FUSION, V32, P271 BHATNAGAR VP, 1981, CONTROLLED FUSIO B 1, V14, P255 BREUN R, 1991, FUSION TECHNOL, V19, P1327 CORONADO M, 1993, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V5, P1200 DIEBOLD D, 1990, REV SCI INSTRUM, V61, P2870 DOYLE EJ, 1991, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V3, P2300 GROEBNER RJ, 1990, PHYS REV LETT, V64, P3015 IDA K, 1992, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V4, P2552 LOHR JM, 1987, PHYS REV LETT, V58, P124 MIURA Y, 1990, 13TH P INT C WASH, V1, P325 RHODES TL, 1993, NUCL FUSION, V33, P1787 ROZHANSKY V, 1992, PHYS FLUIDS B-PLASMA, V4, P1877 SCHAUBEL KM, 1990, J VAC SCI TECHNOL A, V8, P3063 SCHISSEL DP, 1989, CONTROLLED FUSIO B 1, V13, P115 TAYLOR RJ, 1989, PHYS REV LETT, V63, P2365 TAYLOR RJ, 1991, PLASMA PHYS CONTROLL, V1, P463 TSUJI S, 1991, PLASMA PHYS CONTROLL, V1, P659 TYNAN GR, 1992, PHYS REV LETT, V68, P3032 WAGNER F, 1982, PHYS REV LETT, V49, P1408 WEYNANTS RR, 1990, NUCL FUSION, V30, P945 WEYNANTS RR, 1992, NUCL FUSION, V32, P837 WINTER J, 1990, J NUCL MATER, V176, P486 ZWEBEN SJ, 1982, J NUCL MATER, V111, P39; NR: 23; TC: 12; J9: NUCL FUSION; PG: 8; GA: QY829

z:row.TitlePrimary: Interaction of Alfven Waves with Biased H-Mode Plasmas in Phaedrus-T
z:row.Keyword: RADIAL ELECTRIC-FIELD|POLOIDAL ROTATION|TCA TOKAMAK|TRANSITIONS|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas|Physics, Nuclear
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: VIENNA; WAGRAMERSTRASSE 5 PO BOX 100, A-1400 VIENNA, AUSTRIA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SW INST PHYS,CHENGDU 610041,PEOPLES R CHINA. JOHNS HOPKINS UNIV,DEPT PHYS & ASTRON,BALTIMORE,MD 21218.; WANG, X, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Data are presented showing the first demonstration that Il mode plasmas can be produced with a biased electrode in the presence of substantial auxiliary power (the Alfven wave power was roughly twice the corresponding ohmic power). The data also show the first demonstration of Alfven wave heating of electrons during an Il mode. Although the H mode has been produced in some tokamaks (without the use of a biased electrode) by auxiliary heating greater than a threshold value dependent on plasma conditions and the auxiliary heating method, for the first time, measurements presented here Show that subthreshold Alfven wave power increases the edge particle transport (in both ohmic and Il mode plasmas) and that this auxiliary power degrades rather than enhances the biased electrode H mode. In addition, for the first time, it is shown that Alfven waves generated by +pi/2 (as compared with pi) phasing result in greater RF fuelling in H mode plasmas.

z:row.TitlePrimary: How does the Potential Get from a to B in a Plasma
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: HERSHKOWITZ, N, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Solutions to the question of how the plasma potential varies from point A to point B, at which the values are specified, are discussed. Each answer depends on plasma and boundary conditions. Plasma potential structures measured by emissive probes are considered. Examples include potentials associated with sheaths and presheaths in collisionless and collisional systems, unmagnetized and magnetized double layers with single and multiple step transitions, semiconductor etching and rf self bias, tandem mirror plasma confinement and tokamak antenna impurity production. DC structures, time average structures associated with capacitive and inductive rf and the role of potential well pumping are considered.

z:row.TitlePrimary: The Phaedrus-T Antenna System
z:row.Keyword: ICRF HEATING EXPERIMENTS|IMPURITY GENERATION|TOKAMAK|JFT-2M|Nuclear Science & Technology
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: MAJESKI, R, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A two strap fast wave antenna has been developed which is capable of operating at arbitrary phasing for any level of plasma loading resistance. Recent advances in the understanding of the rf-edge plasma interaction have been incorporated in the design as well. The result is an antenna which operates without Faraday shielding while greatly reducing rf-induced scrape-off layer perturbations and impurity influx.
