z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental studies of multimode helicon plasma waves
z:row.Keyword: Plasma waves|Helicons|Antennas|Magnetic fields|Electron density measurement|Plasma density|Electromagnetic wave propagation in plasma|Mathematical models|Calculations|Probes
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Physics Publishing Ltd, Bristol, Engl
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Helicon waves were excited by a Nagoya type III antenna in a steady state argon magnetized plasma column with DC magnetic field BO = 400-500 G, electron density 1012-1013 cm-3 and neutral species pressure about 20 mTorr. Wavelength measurements made with B-dot probes at the edge of the plasma column show the presence of multimode standing helicon waves. Azimuthal mode numbers m = + 1, 0 and - 1 were detected with m = + 1 dominant. Radial density profiles were measured with Langmuir probes. The wavelength measurements are shown to agree with theoretical calculations of helicon waves in radially non-uniform plasma.

z:row.Abstract: Computer modeling of Nagoya Type III and helical antennas, used to excite helicon waves, has been carried out with the code ANTENA. The code considers a cylindrical plasma with an arbitrary radial density and temperature profile and realistic antenna structures, in a uniform magnetic field. We report investigations of the role of radio frequency radial ponderomotive force in providing magnetohydrodynamic stability of the helicon plasma with emphasis on the roles of the m=+1 and m=0 azimuthal modes. Both antenna structures are shown to be ponderomotively stable with most of the stability coming from the near field

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma fueling by sputtering and gas desorption during high power RF operation on the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1995 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.95CH35796)
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|boron compounds|desorption|fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor limiters|plasma collision processes|plasma diagnostics|plasma flow|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma-wall interactions|sputtering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. The particle confinement time in tokamaks, τp, is at least an order of magnitude less than the length of the discharge. In order to maintain a constant density during the discharge, it is necessary to provide an external hydrogen fueling source. On Phaedrus-T, approximately 4×1017 hydrogen atoms per millisecond must be puffed into the vessel to maintain a constant density. Ion impact onto materials within the vacuum vessel causes sputtering and gas desorption, and these processes provide an additional uncontrolled fueling source. On the Phaedrus-T tokamak, high power RF (100-400 kW, 4-7 MHz) operation increases the sputtering and gas desorption rates. This increased gas influx, called RF fueling, can lead to disruptions or create ambiguity in interpreting the nature of the RF physics. Antenna designs have played a critical role in determining the amount of RF fueling that occurs. On Phaedrus-T, insulating boron nitride (BN) protection limiters intercept the plasma flow to the antenna straps. This is different from conventional tokamak antenna designs which surround their antenna with a conducting shield
z:row.User2: gas desorption; high power RF operation; sputtering; plasma fueling; Phaedrus-T tokamak; particle confinement time; external hydrogen fueling source; Ion impact; vacuum vessel; uncontrolled fueling source; RF operation; gas influx; RF fueling; RF physics; antenna designs; tokamak antenna designs; antenna straps; plasma flow; BN; protection limiters; 100 to 400 kW; 4 to 7 MHz

z:row.Abstract: Phaedrus-T is an ISX class tokamak (B⩽1T, R≃0.9m, a≃0.25m, Ip≃100 kA, ne(0)≃2×1019/m3 and Te(0)~500 eV), which began operation in 1989. Measurements of the Phaedrus-T edge plasma parameters have been made with triple probes, swept Langmuir probes, swept emissive probes, self-emissive probes, reciprocating probes, capacitive probes and shadowed probes of various sizes and materials. ICRF current drive studies are the focus of the Phaedrus-T program; and, consequently, most Phaedrus-T probe measurements have been of ICRF/edge plasma interactions. Data showed strong ICRF modifications of the edge plasma when an antenna with a conventional stainless steel Faraday shield was used; greatly reduced ICRF/edge coupling when 1/4 inch boron nitride side limiters were placed on the Faraday shield; and no significant change in the ICRF/edge coupling when the Faraday shield was later removed (even though there was a significant reduction in plasma impurities)
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-T tokamak probe measurements; ISX class tokamak; edge plasma parameters; triple probes; swept Langmuir probes; swept emissive probes; self-emissive probes; reciprocating probes; capacitive probes; shadowed probes; ICRF current drive; ICRF-edge plasma interactions; antenna; stainless steel Faraday shield; BN side limiters; ICRF-edge coupling; plasma impurities

z:row.TitlePrimary: A new ion pitch-angle diagnostic for magnetized plasmas
z:row.Keyword: nitrogen|organic compounds|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma sheaths|plasma temperature|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An ion pitch-angle diagnostic (PAD) capable of directly measuring the ratio Ti⊥/Ez in a magnetized plasma is described. It consists of an ion collector, a plane stainless steel electrode with its axis parallel to magnetic lines of force, which can be slid along the inside of a stainless steel cylindrical tube of inner radius R. The ion collector is insulated from the tube and is biased to a negative potential to collect ions. Calculations show that the ratio I/I0 of the collected ion current, when the collector is withdrawn a distance z from the tube entrance, to the ion current collected at z=0, depends solely on the ratio of Ti⊥/Ez. The change of I/I0 with z is found to be insensitive to the absolute magnitude of Ti⊥ and Ez, and to the mass of the ion species. PAD results are presented for N2 and CF4 plasmas. Results for N2 plasmas are shown to compare well with LIF (laser-induced fluorescence) results demonstrating the validity of this diagnostic
z:row.User2: carbon tetrafluoride; ion pitch-angle diagnostic; magnetized plasmas; ion collector; plane stainless steel electrode; magnetic lines of force; stainless steel cylindrical tube; negative potential; ion current; N2

z:row.TitlePrimary: How does the potential get from A to B in a plasma?
z:row.Keyword: Plasmas|Plasma probes|Tokamak devices|Etching|Electron emission|Electrons|Thermal effects|Magnetic fields|Plasma sheaths|Plasma diagnostics
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Solutions to the question of how the plasma potential varies from point A to point B, at which the values are specified, are discussed. Each answer depends on plasma and boundary conditions. Plasma potential structures measured by emissive probes are considered. Examples include potentials associated with sheaths and presheaths in collisionless and collisional systems, unmagnetized and magnetized double layers with single and multiple step transitions, semiconductor etching and rf self bias, tandem mirror plasma confinement and tokamak antenna impurity production. DC structures, time average structures associated with capacitive and inductive rf and the role of potential well pumping are considered.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma potential structure; Emissive probe; Semiconductor etching; Langmuir probe

z:row.TitlePrimary: Linear and nonlinear ion beam instabilities in a double plasma device
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, Jun 6-8 1994
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
z:row.Keyword: Ion beams|Plasma stability|Plasma devices|Electrons|Ions|Beam plasma interactions|Plasma probes|Temperature
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion beam instabilities in the double plasma device DOLI-1 were found to be quite sensitive to the difference between the source and target chamber plasma potentials when those potentials were within an electron temperature Te/e or so of each other. When the target chamber plasma potential of DOLI-1 was /e or so of each other. When the target chamber plasma potential of DOLI-1 was e/e more positive than the source chamber plasma potential, a global ion beam-ion beam instability was observed. On the other hand, when the maximum target potential was between approximately 0.5 Te/e and 2.0 Te/e below the source potential, an ion-ion beam instability and a soliton associated with it were observed. This soliton is unique in that it is not launched but rather is self generated by the plasma and beam. When the target potential was less than source potential by more than two or so Te/e, the plasma was quite quiescent, which allowed small amplitude wave packet launched by Langmuir probe to be detected.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Ion beam instabilities; Target chamber plasma potentials; Electron temperature; Solitons; Langmuir probe

z:row.TitlePrimary: Space charge enhanced, plasma gradient induced error in satellite electric field measurements
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In magnetospheric plasmas it is possible for plasma gradients to cause error in electric field measurements made by satellite double probes. The space charge enhanced plasma gradient induced error is discussed in general terms, the results of a laboratory experiment designed to illustrate this error are presented, and a simple expression that quantifies this error in a form that is readily applicable to satellite data is derived. The simple expression indicates that for a given probe bias current there is less error for cylindrical probes than for spherical probes. The expression also suggests that for Viking data the error is negligible
z:row.User2: magnetosphere; measurement technique; artificial satellite; plasma probe; plasma diagnostics; space charge enhanced; plasma gradient induced error; electric field; double probe; probe bias current; cylindrical probe; spherical probe; Viking

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experiments with back side gas cooling using an electrostatic wafer holder in an electron cyclotron resonance etching tool
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Wafer temperature, etch rate, and etch uniformity measurements of SiO2 wafers were made to characterize the use of back side helium cooling with an electrostatic wafer holder in an electron cyclotron resonance etching tool. The etch rate was found to be independent of the wafer temperature in the range between 20 and 110°C. A 7% increase in etch nonuniformity (3σ) at higher backside pressures was attributed to helium, which leaked around the edge of the wafer, displacing the etchant gas. A back side pressure of 2-3 Torr provides a balance between wafer temperature control and helium leak rates
z:row.User2: ECR etching; back side gas cooling; electrostatic wafer holder; wafer temperature; etch rate; etch uniformity; SiO2 wafers; etch nonuniformity; 20 to 110 degC; SiO2

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma sheaths near a negatively step biased electrode-dynamic behavior for planar and spherical geometry
z:row.Keyword: electrodes|plasma boundary layers|plasma sheaths|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A numerical solution of fluid equations coupled with Poisson's equation is used to study the temporal evolution of plasma sheaths near a negatively biased electrode. Special attention is paid to long-time behavior of the sheath and to mechanisms of sheath stabilization in a collisionless plasma. The crucial influence of the system geometry on the sheath behavior and the asymptotic potential profile are established. Dynamic structures in plasma and geometrical factors are found to provide presheath ion acceleration which determine the conditions at the sheath boundary and play an important role in sheath stabilization
z:row.User2: planar geometry; negatively step biased electrode; dynamic behavior; spherical geometry; numerical solution; fluid equations; Poisson's equation; temporal evolution; plasma sheaths; long-time behavior; sheath stabilization; collisionless plasma; asymptotic potential profile; presheath ion acceleration; sheath boundary

z:row.TitlePrimary: Chemical etching of SiO2 by CF4, at low pressure - does it really depend on the plasma chemistry?
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, Jun 6-8 1994
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Etching of SiO2 by fluorine based plasmas is generally viewed as a complicated process which involves dozens of chemical reactions. There is little doubt that such etching is a chemical process rather than sputtering. Nevertheless, experimental results are presented which show that the etch rate of SiO2 etching by CF4/O2/CHF3/Ar plasma in an ECR tool depends only on the ion energy flux to the SiO2 wafer and is insensitive to the plasma composition as long as sufficient F is present. Experiments were carried out at 0.5-3 mtorr. Measurements show that the etch rate does not depend on the concentration of CF4, CF3, CF2 or F. Similar results have been found for Si etching. The meaning of 'sufficient F' will be discussed as well as a comparison to ion beam etching.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Ion energy flux; Carbon tetrafluoride; Ion beam etching; Electron cyclotron resonance

z:row.TitlePrimary: Alfven wave analysis for Phaedrus-T
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of International Sherwood Fusion Theory Conference, 14-16 March 1994
z:row.Keyword: dispersion relations|numerical analysis|plasma heating|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma transport processes|plasma waves
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Dallas, TX, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Alfven wave plasma heating and current drive experiments are in progress at the Phaedrus-T tokamak. Preliminary experimental results suggest nonsymmetry in wave penetration along the torus relative to the direction of the ohmic current. To theoretically analyze this feature it was found necessary to include the poloidal magnetic field effects into the consideration. The report is devoted to the numerical analysis of the experimental situation in the Phaedrus-T tokamak. For these purposes, the full-wave code, FASTWAC, has been amended to include the poloidal magnetic field effects. The theoretical and numerical results on Alfven wave dispersion relation, 2D distribution of wave fields, and absorbed power inside the plasma are presented. The nonsymmetry in wave field structure for the waves penetrating in opposite directions along the torus (opposite toroidal wave numbers) has been obtained in calculations. The final goal of these studies is to find the most promising regimes for Alfven wave current drive in tokamaks
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-T tokamak; Alfven wave analysis; Alfven wave plasma heating; Alfven wave current drive experiments; wave penetration; ohmic current; poloidal magnetic field effects; numerical analysis; full-wave code; FASTWAC; dispersion relation; 2D wave field distribution; absorbed power; plasma; wave field structure

z:row.TitlePrimary: Phaedrus-T antenna system
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak devices|Antenna phased arrays|Design|Plasma heating|Cyclotron resonance|Wave plasma interactions|Impurities
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Elsevier Sequoia SA, Lausanne, Switz
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A two strap fast wave antenna has been developed which is capable of operating at arbitrary phasing for any level of plasma loading resistance. Recent advances in the understanding of the rf-edge plasma interaction have been incorporated in the design as well. The result is an antenna which operates without Faraday shielding while greatly reducing rf-induced scrape-off layer perturbations and impurity influx.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-T tokamak; Two strap fast wave antenna; Radio frequency-edge plasma interactions; Radio frequency-induced scrape-off layer perturbations; Impurity influx

z:row.TitlePrimary: The influence of multiple ion species on Alfven wave dispersion and Alfven wave plasma heating
z:row.Keyword: plasma heating|plasma impurities|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Phaedrus Lab. for Plasma Sci., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, the effects of light impurities, such as deuterium, helium, or carbon, on Alfven wave dispersion characteristics are explored. It is shown that a small population of light impurities in a hydrogen plasma modify the dispersion of the: global Alfven waves and the Alfven continuum in such a way that the wave frequency depends weakly on the toroidal wave number. It is also shown that the global Alfven wave enters into the Alfven continuum. Under these conditions, it is possible to heat plasma efficiently by employing an antenna with a broad toroidal wavelength spectrum. The relationship between impurity concentration and the efficiency of Alfven wave heating is explored. Under appropriate conditions, the results indicate that in the presence of impurities, Alfven waves can heat electrons predominantly in the central part of the plasma. This effect is explored via a series of numerical calculations of the heating specifically for the Phaedrus-T Alfven wave heating experiment [Phys. Fluids B 5, 2506 (1993)]
z:row.User2: multiple ion species; Alfven wave dispersion; Alfven wave plasma heating; light impurities; D; He; C; H plasma; wave frequency; toroidal wave number; antenna; broad toroidal wavelength spectrum; impurity concentration; Alfven wave heating; numerical calculations; Phaedrus-T Alfven wave heating experiment

z:row.TitlePrimary: Absolute fluorine atom concentrations in RIE and ECR CF4 plasmas measured by actinometry
z:row.Keyword: chemical variables measurement|organic compounds|plasma diagnostics|plasma radiofrequency heating|radiometry|sputter etching
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Mater. Sci. Program, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: We have measured the absolute fluorine atom concentrations in electron cyclotron resonance (ECR) and reactive ion etching (RIE) plasmas by optimizing the actinometry technique. The major difference between this work and conventional actinometry is that the Ar concentration measurements were performed by a residual gas analyser (RGA). The emission intensities of F (7037 Å) and Ar (7504 Å) were simultaneously measured by an optical multichannel analyser (OMA) and the Ar concentration by a RGA. The F atom concentration at the wafer stage in the CF4 ECR plasma was measured to be (0.4 to 4)×1012 cm-3, the microwave power from 500 to 900 W, pressure from 0.5 (3.7 sccm) to 3.5 mTorr (58 sccm), and a fixed RF bias voltage of -50 V. The F atom concentration of the CF4 ECR plasma was four times larger in the source region than in the downstream region. The F atom concentration of the CF4 RIE plasma for pressures from 13 to 82 mTorr was measured as (0.8 to 4.2)×1013 cm-3, for a CF4 flow rate of 20 sccm, and power inputs from 250 to 1500 W. The F atom concentration was larger in the RIE etcher than in the ECR etcher, but the F atom production efficiency was eight times larger in the ECR etcher than in the RIE etcher for the same power level. In spite of the possibility of a factor two discrepancy in the measurements from absolute values because of the uncertainty in the absolute values of the cross sections, this technique provides a relatively simple and consistent reproducible measurement of F atom concentration to compare operation of the two types of etchers, which is reproducible to ±10%. We further explored the actinometry for vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) emission region by using F (955 Å) and Ar (1048 Å). A similar trend of F atom concentration was found as for the visible actinometry, but the absolute value of fluorine atom concentration was typically 15% larger for the VUV actinometry
z:row.User2: methyl tetrafluoromethane plasmas; actinometry; absolute F atom concentrations; reactive ion etching plasmas; electron cyclotron resonance plasmas; residual gas analyser; emission intensities; optical multichannel analyser; microwave power; fixed RF bias voltage; factor two discrepancy; vacuum ultraviolet emission; 7037 A; 7504 A; 0.5 to 3.5 mtorr; 13 to 82 mtorr; 250 to 1500 W; -50 V; 955 A; 1048 A

z:row.TitlePrimary: On rf “helicity injection” and Alfven wave current drive
z:row.TitleSecondary: Tenth Topical Conference on Radio Frequency Power in Plasmas, 1-3 April 1993

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Boston, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: We discuss the dynamo effect due to low-frequency waves in connection with recently proposed current-drive schemes. We focus on nonresonant thermal effects and discuss the role of wave helicity in two-fluid theory
z:row.User2: RF helicity injection; Alfven wave current drive; dynamo effect; low-frequency waves; current-drive schemes; nonresonant thermal effects; wave helicity; two-fluid theory

z:row.TitlePrimary: Multiple magnetized double layers in the laboratory
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Even though there have been many experimental observations of various types of double layers (DL), laboratory data thus far have only produced special examples of the more general case of multiple magnetized double layers. A series of stationary, fully magnetized (ions and electrons), two-dimensional (both parallel and transverse to the magnetic field) weak double layers (DLs) with three, four, or more potential steps has been observed in a laboratory experiment for the first time. They may play important roles in the auroral zone, the physics of solar flares, high-power gas lasers, and laser pellet ablation plasmas. The transverse electric fields are, on average, larger than the parallel ones, and the transverse spatial size scales with ion gyroradius. The total number of DL potential drops depends on the location and what particular path is followed across any given potential profile. Electron beams acquire additional directed energy across these DLs along with heating of the bulk distribution and large fluctuating energy density
z:row.User2: 2D double layers; electron beams; multiple magnetized double layers; auroral zone; solar flares; high-power gas lasers; laser pellet ablation plasmas; transverse electric fields; transverse spatial size scales; ion gyroradius; potential drops; potential profile; heating; bulk distribution; fluctuating energy density

z:row.TitlePrimary: Etching rate characterization of SiO2 and Si using ion energy flux and atomic fluorine density in a CF4/O2/Ar electron cyclotron resonance plasma
z:row.TitleSecondary: 39th American Vacuum Society National Symposium, 9-13 Nov. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: SiO2 and Si etching in a CF4/O2/Ar plasma has been carried out in an electron cyclotron resonance etcher over a wide range of conditions. The etch rate has been compared with the ion energy flux to the wafer surface, JiEi, and the atomic fluorine density in the gas phase, nF. It is found that the etch rate can be divided into two regimes by a critical value of nF/(JiEi), the ratio of the atomic fluorine density to the ion energy flux. The critical value can be determined from a contour plot of the etch rate as a function of the ion energy flux and the atomic fluorine density. The critical value of nF/(JiEi) for Si is higher than that for SiO2. For nF/(JiEi) higher than the critical value, the SiO2 etch rate linearly increases with the ion energy flux, and the Si etch rate shows a nonlinear increase with the ion energy flux. For nF/(JiEi) lower than the critical value, both SiO2 and Si etch rates linearly increase with the atomic fluorine density
z:row.User2: semiconductor; ion energy flux; electron cyclotron resonance plasma; etch rate; SiO2; Si; F

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison of the effects of an ICRF antenna with insulating side limiters with and without a Faraday screen on the edge parameters of a tokamak plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The PHAEDRUS-T tokamak was operated with radiofrequency power near the ion cyclotron frequency at 90° phasing between two current straps with and without a stainless steel Faraday screen covering the antenna. In both cases, the sides of the antenna were protected by insulating limiters. The plasma parameters in the scrape-off layer were measured and were shown to be essentially the same when radiofrequency power was applied from the Faraday screen covered antenna as compared with the antenna without a Faraday screen. The intensity of Fe(XVI) light dropped an order of magnitude after the screen was removed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Faraday screens; ICRF antennas; PHAEDRUS-T tokamak

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma characterization and process control diagnostics
z:row.TitleSecondary: 39th American Vacuum Society National Symposium, 9-13 Nov. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Diagnostics are needed both for plasma characterization and for plasma processing control. Normally, different diagnostics are employed. Process control relies on the ability to measure data dependent on charged and neutral particle parameters as well as on in situ surface diagnostics. Gas phase diagnostics employed at the University of Wisconsin Engineering Research Center for Plasma-Aided Manufacturing provide examples of both types of diagnostics. Both invasive and noninvasive diagnostics are employed. Invasive diagnostics such as probes are useful for characterizing the plasma but are usually not useful for control. Control is best provided by noninvasive diagnostics. Many noninvasive diagnostics, such as laser induced fluorescence are not suitable for control because they are too finicky or too inconvenient to use. Because monitoring the process in situ usually doesn't work, it is recommended that characterization be aimed at identifying key parameters to be used for control. The specific problem of controlling the SiO2 etch rate with CF4/O2/CHF3/Ar in an electron cyclotron resonance tool is discussed as an example of this approach. The current status of our attempts at real-time control is given
z:row.User2: gas phase diagnostics; charged particle parameters; process control diagnostics; plasma characterization; plasma processing control; neutral particle parameters; surface diagnostics; noninvasive diagnostics

z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record - Abstracts 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA

z:row.Abstract: Phaedrus-T is an ISX class tokamak which began operation in 1989. Measurements of the Phaedrus-T edge plasma parameters have been made with triple probes swept Langmuir probes, swept emissive probes self-emissive probes reciprocating probes, capacitive probes and sshadowed probes of various sizes and materials. Data obtained with these probes will be presented; and the techniques used to obtain these data, as well difficulties encountered and the successes in overcoming these difficulties, will be discussed. ICRF current drive studies are the focus of the Phaedrus-T program; and consequently, most Phaedrus-T probe measurements, have been of ICRF/edge plasma interactions. z:row.TitlePrimary: Investigation of a wave packet instability
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record - Abstracts 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recently, probe measurements in the triple plasma device DOLI-1 and in a multidipole soup-pot plasma device have shown, under certain conditions, a wave packet instability near the ion plasma frequency. This wave packet instability is similar to the continuous 'double-plasma instability' found by Barret and Greaves and has been shown to be useful as convenient measure of plasma flow. These wave packets and the mechanism that generates them are not yet well understood. The existence of the sheath, in our case the sheath at the grid between the source and target chambers of DOLI-1 and at the wall of the soup-pot. Among other wave packet characteristics, the authors will present data showing the wave packet amplitude in the sheath and potential drop across the sheath.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Wave packet instability; Triple plasma device DOLI-1; Plasma flow measurement; Mutidipole soup-pot plasma device; Ion plasma frequency

z:row.TitlePrimary: Characterization of an ECR etching plasma with a microwave interferometer, langmuir probes and a FTIR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record - Abstracts 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Characterization of an etching plasma includes both plasma electrons and ions and neutral species composition ERC etching plasmas with high density, and low neutral pressure can have appreciably different neutral and ion species concentrations than RF parallel plate systems. We have partially characterized an ECR etching device by using a microwave interferometer in the source region and Langmuir probes and an FTIR in the downstream target region. The microwave interferometer gives a measure of the line averaged density in the source and is present for all the measurements. For a given set of conditions, the Langmuir probes are used to measure the plasma density and electron temperature radial profiles in the downstream region. The FTIR monitors the neutral gas concentration of the etching feed gas, CF4.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Langmuir probe measurements of electron temperature and density scaling in multidipole radio frequency plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: 39th American Vacuum Society National Symposium, 9-13 Nov. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors have constructed a multidipole RF plasma system in a bell jar with a single planar RF powered electrode inserted at one end of a `magnetic bucket'. Capacitance probe measurements revealed that the RF fluctuations are particularly large in these capacitively coupled plasmas. A Langmuir probe has been developed, in which a large shunting capacitor and several self-resonant inductors are used to allow the probe tip to follow the RF fluctuations. With this new probe, they are able to adequately suppress the effect of these large RF fluctuations and measure time averaged plasma densities and electron temperatures or electron energy distribution functions (EEDFs). They report here a series of experiments in argon with the Langmuir probe fixed at the center of the plasma. The EEDFs were found to be Maxwellian with temperatures from 2 to 5 eV. The value of Te depends primarily on pressure, which was varied from 0.5 to 2.5 mTorr. The plasma density exhibited an approximately linear relationship with AelVrf/Te, where Ael is the area of the powered electrode, and VRF is the RF voltage on the powered electrode
z:row.User2: Langmuir probe measurements; electron temperature; density scaling; multidipole radio frequency plasmas; multidipole RF plasma system; bell jar; single planar RF powered electrode; magnetic bucket; RF fluctuations; large shunting capacitor; several self-resonant inductors; electron energy distribution functions; plasma density

z:row.TitlePrimary: How does the potential get from A to B in a plasma?
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Sciences (ICOPS), 7-9 June 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.93CH3334-0)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Vancouver, BC, Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. It is noted that the question, how does the potential get from A to B in a plasma, has important consequences for basic plasmas, plasmas in the Earth's magnetosphere, plasmas in tandem mirrors and in tokamaks, and plasmas used in plasma processing. In solving the problem, nature may have created auroras. The answer often depends on whether the reference frame is moving or stationary and on the dimensionality of the problem. Until recently, the answer made it impossible to carry out many RF experiments in tokamaks but provided a key ingredient to semiconductor etching and some axial plugging in tandem mirrors
z:row.User2: potential; plasma; Earth's magnetosphere; tandem mirrors; tokamaks; plasma processing; reference frame; dimensionality; semiconductor etching; axial plugging

z:row.TitlePrimary: Alfven wave experiments in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: 34th Annual Meeting of the Division of Plasma Physics of the American Physical Society, 16-20 Nov. 1992
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|plasma diagnostics|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma waves
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Heating in the Alfven resonant regime has been demonstrated in the Phaedrus-T tokamak [Fusion Technol. 19, 1327 (1991)]. Electron heating during injection of radio-frequency (RF) power is indicated by a 30%-40% drop in loop voltage and modifications in sawtooth activity. Heating was observed at a frequency ωrf≈0.7 Ωi on axis, using a two-strap fast wave antenna operated at 76 and 9.2 MHz with 180° phasing (N∥~100). Numerical modeling with the fast wave code FASTWA [Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion 33, 417 (1991)] indicates that for Phaedrus-T parameters the kinetic Alfven wave is excited via mode conversion from a surface fast wave at the Alfven resonance and is subsequently damped on electrons

z:row.TitlePrimary: Investigations of a wave packet instability
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Sciences (ICOPS), 7-9 June 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.93CH3334-0)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Vancouver, BC, Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. Probe measurements in the triple plasma device DOLI-1 and in a multidipole soup-pot plasma device have shown, under certain conditions, a wave packet instability near the ion plasma frequency. This instability is similar to the continuous double-plasma instability found by P.J. Barret and R.G. Greaves (1989) and has been shown to be useful as a convenient measure of plasma flow. These wave packets and the mechanism that generates them are not well understood. The existence of the wave packets seems to depend on the presence of a sheath, in the present case the sheath at the grid between the source and target chambers of DOLI-1 and at the wall of the soup-pot. Among other wave packet characteristics, data have been obtained, showing the wave packet amplitude δn/n (where n is the local plasma density) vs. both location in the sheath and potential drop across the sheath
z:row.User2: triple plasma device DOLI-1; multidipole soup-pot plasma device; wave packet instability; ion plasma frequency; continuous double-plasma instability; plasma flow; sheath; wave packet characteristics; potential drop

z:row.TitlePrimary: Characterization of an ECR etching plasma with a microwave interferometer, Langmuir probes and a FTIR
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Sciences (ICOPS), 7-9 June 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.93CH3334-0)
z:row.Keyword: electromagnetic wave interferometry|Fourier transform spectroscopy|infrared spectroscopy|interferometry|Langmuir probes|microwave measurement|plasma density|plasma diagnostics|plasma flow|plasma pressure|plasma temperature|sputter etching
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Vancouver, BC, Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. The authors have partially characterized an ECR (electron cyclotron resonance) etching device by using a microwave interferometer in the source region and Langmuir probes and an FTIR (Fourier transform infrared) in the downstream target region. The microwave interferometer gives a measure of the line averaged density in the source and is present for all the measurements. For a given set of conditions, the Langmuir probes are used to measure the plasma density and electron temperature radial profiles in the downstream region. The FTIR monitors the neutral gas concentration of the etching feed gas, CF4. The interferometer is used to cross check that the conditions are similar. With the feed gas in the source region, the line averaged plasma at 1012 cm-3, and neutral pressure below 2 mTorr, a significant fraction (80%) of the CF4 feed gas is `burned out' by the plasma. This fraction varies with the neutral pressure, gas flow rate, and plasma density. This is consistent with a 2-D plasma-`chemistry' code developed to model this ECR system. The code predicts that varying the feed gas location should also vary the neutral composition
z:row.User2: tetrafluoromethane; carbon tetrafluoride; ECR etching plasma; microwave interferometer; Langmuir probes; downstream target region; line averaged density; plasma density; electron temperature radial profiles; neutral gas concentration; etching feed gas; line averaged plasma; neutral pressure; gas flow rate; feed gas location; neutral composition; 2 mtorr

z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Sciences (ICOPS), 7-9 June 1993

z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. Measurements of the Phaedrus-T edge plasma parameters have been made with triple probe, swept Langmuir probes, swept emissive probes, self-emissive probes, reciprocating probes, capacitive probes, and shadowed probes of various sizes and materials. ICRF current drive studies are the focus of the Phaedrus-T program; and, consequently, most Phaedrus-T probe measurements have been of ICRF/edge plasma interactions. Data have been obtained that show strong ICRF modifications of edge plasmas when an antenna with a conventional, stainless steel Faraday shield was used; greatly reduced ICRF/edge coupling when boron nitride side limiters were placed on the Faraday shield; and no significant change in the ICRF/edge coupling when the Faraday shield was later removed (even though there was a significant reduction in plasma impurities)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Direct measurement of plasma flow velocity using a Langmuir probe
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma flow velocity was determined experimentally from the time delay between fluctuations measured by two spatially separated Langmuir probes in both subsonic and supersonic, steady-state, unmagnetized plasma flows

z:row.TitlePrimary: Two-dimensional mapping of plasma parameters using probes in an electron cyclotron resonance etching device
z:row.TitleSecondary: 39th American Vacuum Society National Symposium, 9-13 Nov. 1992

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Emissive probe measurements of plasma potentials outside the source aperture of an electron cyclotron resonance etching device have shown large radial electric fields in a nitrogen discharge. It is shown that the magnitude of the radial electric field is pressure dependent decreasing for higher pressures. In addition to radial and axial profiles of the plasma potential, profiles of ion density, electron temperature, and floating potential were measured with Langmuir probes for several cases: Two magnetic-field configurations, with and without an insulating liner in the source, and with and without a wafer stage. It is shown that the plasma potential with the liner present is higher when there is a resonance zone close to the aperture of the source, as opposed to when the resonance zone is farther inside the source
z:row.User2: plasma parameters; probes; electron cyclotron resonance etching device; plasma potentials; large radial electric fields; pressure dependent; ion density; electron temperature; floating potential

z:row.TitlePrimary: Study of a parallel mode launch into a magnetic beach
z:row.Keyword: Cyclotrons|Magnetic fields|Mirrors|Mathematical models|Electromagnetic wave propagation in plasma|Electromagnetic wave refraction|Electromagnetic wave polarization|Electromagnetic dispersion|Plasma density|Measurements
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A parallel mode launch in the electron cyclotron range of frequencies has been performed on axis in the east end cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. Propagation of the energy launched toward a magnetic beach in a radially hollow density profile was studied experimentally. A strong refractive dispersal of the energy launched was observed and shown to be in good agreement with a WKB type ray tracing model using a cold plasma Appleton-Hartree dispersion relation. Measurements of plasma density and electron temperature indicate that the use of this dispersion relation is well justified. These results are compared with additional ray tracing studies for radially hollow and nonhollow, high (flaunchp) and low (flaunchgt;fp) density models. For the experimental conditions examined, a `reversal' of refractive behavior is shown to exist as the energy propagates from a low density (flaunchgt;fp) region to a high density (flaunchp) region.

z:row.Abstract: Thin-film interferometry has long been used to monitor deposition and etching processes. This paper presents Lissajous and phase-space graphs of thin-film interferometry traces and discusses some of the practical implications of graphing the data in these non-traditional formats. These types of graphs can highlight certain process events and provide a more user-friendly operator interface for the control of thin-film etching and deposition processes.

z:row.TitlePrimary: X-rays in electron-cyclotron-resonance processing plasmas
z:row.Keyword: plasma applications|plasma diagnostics|plasma pressure|plasma temperature|X-ray production|X-ray spectra
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electron-cyclotron-resonance processing plasmas have been shown to produce low-energy X-rays. X-radiation was detected in nitrogen and CF4 plasmas from energies of 1-17 keV for microwave powers up to 1000 W. The X-ray flux decreased with increasing pressure over the range of 0.5-3.5 mTorr. Temperatures of the hot electrons responsible for creating the X-rays were estimated from the slopes of the X-ray spectra and decreased with increasing pressure. The measured X-ray flux decreased substantially when the magnetic field configuration was changed. Measurable X-radiation is produced whenever a field line that passes through the cyclotron resonance surface intersects the vacuum chamber walls and/or other solid surfaces inside the source chamber

z:row.TitlePrimary: Characterization of edge plasma and turbulence in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 10th International Conference on Plasma-Surface Interactions in Controlled Fusion Devices - PSI-10, Mar 30-Apr 3 1992
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak devices|Plasmas|Plasma turbulence|Plasma heating|Plasma probes|Surfaces|Plasma confinement|Characterization|Transport properties
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Monterey, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A portable fluctuation diagnostic facility, equipped with a fast reciprocating Langmuir probe array, has participated in a collaborative measurements of edge turbulence and transport in the edge plasma of the Phaedrus-T tokamak. As is typical of many other ohmically heated tokamak plasmas, it is found that fluctuation driven particle flux plays an important role in the particle transport and that the normalized fluctuation level has ordering eφp/Tegt;n/ngt;Te/Te and eφp/Tegt;p/p where p = nTe. A comparison is made of Langmuir probe measurements obtained from probe tips of different construction to quantify the poloidal asymmetry in equilibrium plasma parameters observed in the scrape-off layer. Near the last closed flux surface, a shear layer marked by changes in several fluctuation properties was observed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-T tokamak; Edge plasma; Langmuir probe array; Poloidal asymmetry; Scrape off layer; Shear layer

z:row.Abstract: It is shown that the plasma potential and electron temperature of capacitively coupled RF plasmas, confined in a multi-dipole plasma device, can be varied by changing the position of a grounded plate located in the surface multi-dipole magnetic field

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of whistler instability in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental results of whistler instability studies in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror plasma [Phys. Fluids B 2, 787 (1990)] during electron cyclotron resonance heating (ECH) and ion cyclotron range of frequency (ICRF) heating are compared with theoretical models that predict whistler instability. The experimental results suggest that the whistler instability was caused by `warm' anisotropic electrons

z:row.TitlePrimary: Double-layer-relevant laboratory results
z:row.Keyword: Plasma sources|Space research|Electronic properties|Magnetization|Electric space charge|Magnetic fields
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Over the past few years, many double-layer-relevant laboratory experiments have been carried out at the University of Wisconsin. Laboratory stair-step double layers, which resemble three or more weak double layers joined in series, have been produced without ionization for the first time. Double-layer floating potential fluctuations have been investigated and progress has been made in developing a novel technique for measuring electron energy distribution functions in low-density double layers (i.e., λD >> probe dimensions). A new inductive plasma source has been developed. With this source, magnetized double layers can be routinely produced. These magnetized double layers are often weak stair-step double layers that are oblique to the magnetic field. Laboratory data of emitting probe characteristics taken in tenuous plasmas have helped to quantify space-charge-enhanced plasma gradient induced error in double-layer electric field measurements made by satellite double probes. Also, magnetic sheaths have been experimentally studied and compared with theory.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Double layers

z:row.TitlePrimary: Poloidally asymmetric potential increases in tokamak scrape-off layer plasmas by radiofrequency power
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|Langmuir probes|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma sheaths|plasma temperature|plasma toroidal confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Langmuir probe data are presented which show poloidally asymmetric increases in floating potential, electron temperature and, hence, plasma potential on magnetic field lines which map to the Faraday shield of an ICRF antenna in a medium size tokamak, Phaedrus-T, during radiofrequency power injection. These data are consistent with and suggestive of the existence of radiofrequency generated sheath voltages on those field lines
z:row.User2: tokamak scrape-off layer; radiofrequency power; Langmuir probe data; poloidally asymmetric; floating potential; electron temperature; plasma potential; magnetic field lines; Faraday shield; ICRF antenna; medium size tokamak; Phaedrus-T; power injection; sheath voltages

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ponderomotive force effects on temperature-gradient-driven instabilities
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The modification of temperature-gradient-driven instabilities due to the presence of nonuniform radio-frequency fields near the ion cyclotron frequency is investigated in the linear regime. Employing the fluid theory, it is shown that the induced field line compression caused by ion cyclotron range of frequencies (ICRF) fields makes the net parallel compressibility positive, and thus provides a stabilizing influence on the ion-temperature-gradient-driven mode for an appropriately tailored profile of radio-frequency (RF) pressure. Concomitantly, the radial ponderomotive force generates an additional contribution via coupling between the perturbed fluid motion and the equilibrium ponderomotive force and this effect plays the role of dissipation to enhance or decrease the growth of temperature-gradient-driven modes depending upon the sign of RF pressure gradients. For decreased growth of temperature-gradient-driven instabilities, the plasma density gradients and RF pressure gradients must have opposite signs while enhancement in growth arises when both gradients have the same sign. Finally, the kinetic effects associated with these modes are briefly discussed
z:row.User2: radio-frequency pressure; temperature-gradient-driven instabilities; nonuniform radio-frequency fields; ion cyclotron frequency; fluid theory; induced field line compression; ion cyclotron range of frequencies; ion-temperature-gradient-driven mode; ponderomotive force; plasma density gradients

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fast wave damping on non-Maxwellian electrons
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Theoretical studies of fast wave damping on electrons are presented. Different regimes of importance for fast wave plasma heating and current drive in tokamaks are considered. Various cases of Maxwellian and multi-Maxwellian, isotropic and anisotropic electron distribution functions are investigated. In all cases, fast wave damping on electrons is due to three terms: Landau damping, transit-time magnetic pumping (TTMP), and the cross-term effect. Expressions for all these terms are derived for all regimes considered. Although in most cases Landau damping, TTMP, and the cross-term effect are the same order of magnitude, regimes are found that can be referred to as the pure Landau damping regimes, or pure TTMP regimes. A key parameter that defines the character of fast wave damping is found: δα=ϵ2/γαϵϵ3. In simplified form, and far from resonances, it can be written as δα≈-2ω2/ΩiΩeβα, where α specifies the appropriate regime
z:row.User2: non Maxwellian electrons; fast wave damping; plasma; heating; current drive; tokamaks; electron distribution functions; Landau damping; transit-time magnetic pumping; cross-term effect

z:row.Abstract: A portable fluctuation diagnostic facility, equipped with a fast reciprocating Langmuir probe array, has participated in collaborative measurements of edge turbulence and transport in the edge plasma of the Phaedrus-T tokamak. As is typical of many other ohmically heated tokamak plasmas, it is found that fluctuation driven particle flux plays an important role in the particle transport and that the normalized fluctuation level has ordering, eφ˜p/Te/nT˜c/Te and eφ˜p/Tep˜/p where p=nTe. A comparison is made of Langmuir probe measurements obtained from probe tips of different construction to quantify the poloidal asymmetry in equilibrium plasma parameters observed in the scrape-off layer. z:row.TitlePrimary: Radial control of the electrostatic potential in a tandem mirror with quadrupole end cells
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is demonstrated that the radial electrostatic potential in the Phaedrus tandem mirror [Plasma Physics and Controlled Fusion Research, 1984 (International Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, 1985), vol.2, p.265] can be altered using plasma potential control rings (PPC rings) situated at each end of the device. With the PPC rings grounded, the radial electric field in the central cell was directed outward and peaked near the plasma edge. By externally controlling the potentials of the PPC rings, the peak value of the radial electric field was varied by over a factor of 2, obtaining plasmas with a maximum value of the radial electric field E(r)⩽15 V/cm. A simple calculation to model the change in the central cell potential due to a bias voltage applied to the PPC rings is presented
z:row.User2: electrostatic potential; tandem mirror; quadrupole end cells; plasma potential control rings

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of the presheath in an electron cyclotron resonance etching device
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The first direct measurement of a collisional Bohm presheath from plasma potential measurements is given. By measuring the presheath thickness in front of a grounded wafer stage, a determination of the collision mean free path for ions in an electron cyclotron resonance etching tool has been made. Presheaths were measured in N2 and CF4 plasma using an emissive probe. The presheath thickness in N2 was found to be linearly dependent on the mean free path. Measurements of CF4 plasmas, for which the collision cross sections are unknown, have shown results similar to those found for nitrogen. This result has enabled an extrapolation to be made of the effective cross section for collisions in plasmas created from CF4
z:row.User2: carbon tetrafluoride; electron cyclotron resonance etching device; collisional Bohm presheath; grounded wafer stage; collision mean free path; emissive probe; plasmas

z:row.TitlePrimary: Enhanced slow-wave beach heating of mirror plasmas with two-ion species
z:row.Keyword: eigenvalues and eigenfunctions|magnetic mirrors|plasma diagnostics|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma heating in the ion-cyclotron range of frequencies has been examined in a beach-heating configuration of the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror [Phys. Rev. Lett. 51, 1955 (1983)] during scans of the ion species ratio of hydrogen-helium (H-He) and hydrogen-deuterium (H-D) plasmas. Observed changes in the radial profiles of wave magnetic field and plasma parameters during the scans provide evidence of varied fast- and slow-wave eigenmode excitation and absorption. These changes are shown to be in agreement with those expected from wave accessibility considerations. Optimal peak parameters in the plasma core, ne=1.0×1013 cm-3, Te∥=20 eV, Ti∥=140 eV, Ti⊥=450 eV, and β=0.26 at midplane, were obtained for moderate helium or deuterium ion fractions (puffed nHe/ne=nD/ne~0.25). These parameters represent a significant increase in plasma energy density over that obtained under the same conditions with `pure' hydrogen plasmas: ne=7.0×1012 cm-3, Te∥=25 eV, Ti∥=80 eV; Ti⊥=300 eV, and β=0.12
z:row.User2: ICRF heating; enhanced slow-wave beach heating; eigenmode absorption; two-ion species; central cell; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; plasmas; radial profiles; wave magnetic field; eigenmode excitation; plasma core; plasma energy density; H-He; H-D

z:row.TitlePrimary: X-ray diagnostics for electron cyclotron resonance processing plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: 38th National Symposium of the American Vacuum Society, 11-15 Nov. 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electron cyclotron resonance processing plasmas have been shown to produce low-energy X-rays. X-radiation was detected in nitrogen plasmas from energies of 1 to 17 keV for microwave input powers of 800 and 1000 W. The X-ray flux decreased with increasing pressure over the range of 0.5 to 3.5 mTorr. Temperatures corresponding to the component of the electron velocity distributions responsible for creating the X-rays were estimated from the slopes of the tails of the X-ray spectra and also decreased with increasing pressure. The X-ray flux measured by the detector could be decreased substantially by changing the magnetic field configuration. In general, it was found that measurable X-radiation was produced whenever the surface described by the value of magnetic field which corresponds to that for cyclotron resonance intersects the vacuum chamber walls and/or other solid surfaces inside the chamber
z:row.User2: X-ray diagnostics; electron cyclotron resonance processing plasmas; X-ray flux; electron velocity distributions; X-ray spectra; magnetic field configuration; 0.5 to 3.5 mTorr

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of collisions on ion dynamics in electron-cyclotron-resonance plasmas
z:row.Keyword: plasma applications|plasma collision processes|plasma kinetic theory|sputter etching
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A one-dimensional kinetic code is used to study the effect of ion-neutral (charge exchange and elastic scattering) and ion-ion collisions on plasma flow in the downstream region of an electron-cyclotron-resonance plasma etching system. Ions are assumed to leave the source region at the Bohm velocity. Argon, nitrogen, and CF4 plasmas are simulated, assuming that the dominant ion species are Ar+, N2+, and CF3+, respectively. Results show that charge exchange and elastic scattering collisions play a significant role in reducing the electrostatic potential variation in the downstream region. For neutral gas pressure above ~1 mTorr, the potential drop in the downstream region is small, which means that most of the energy with which ions hit the substrate surface is gained while crossing the substrate sheath region. Although the effect of ion-ion collisions on the plasma potential profile and on the ion distribution function is weak, ion-ion collisions are responsible for transferring energy from the parallel to the perpendicular direction and hence increasing the perpendicular ion temperature
z:row.User2: ion neutral collisions; tetrafluoromethane; ion dynamics; one-dimensional kinetic code; electron-cyclotron-resonance plasma etching; Bohm velocity; CF3+; charge exchange; elastic scattering; electrostatic potential; downstream; substrate sheath; ion-ion collisions; plasma potential profile; ion distribution function; ion temperature; 1 mtorr; Ar+; N2+

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma potential enhancement by waves in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies
z:row.Keyword: magnetic mirrors|plasma collision processes|plasma simulation|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Measured ion-confining potentials in a tandem mirror (using only power in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies to form and sustain the plasma) are found to be larger than those predicted by the Boltzmann relation. The behavior of the potentials is explained as a balance of electron collisional inscattering with electron pumping by time-varying axial electric fields. A single-particle following code is used to model the effect of the time-varying axial electric field on electrostatic/magnetic confinement. Magnitudes of the electric fields required to sustain these potentials agree with values predicted by the available plasma wave-field solving codes. Measured scaling of the ion-confining potential is in qualitative agreement with scaling predicted by the model
z:row.User2: plasma potential enhancement; Phaedrus-A; waves; ion cyclotron range of frequencies; ion-confining potentials; tandem mirror; Boltzmann relation; electron collisional inscattering; electron pumping; time-varying axial electric fields; single-particle following code; electrostatic/magnetic confinement; plasma wave-field solving codes; scaling; model

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beach heating of a two-ion-species mirror plasma
z:row.TitleSecondary: Physics of Alternative Magnetic Confinement Schemes. Proceedings of the Workshop, 15-24 Oct. 1990
z:row.TitleTertiary: Physics of Alternative Magnetic Confinement Schemes. Proceedings of the Workshop
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|magnetic mirrors|plasma density|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma waves
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Varenna, Italy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion heating by ICRF has been investigated in two ion species plasmas in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. The heating can be thought of as a two step process. Waves propagate from the antenna through a radial density gradient and excite eigenmode fields. Heating is accomplished when the slow shear Alfven wave component in the bulk plasma propagates along the magnetic field, through a steep axial magnetic field gradient, into a region of strong ion cyclotron resonance absorption (i.e. a magnetic beach). Both direct excitation of shear Alfven waves and mode conversion of magnetosonic to shear Alven waves are possible, depending on the relative species concentrations. Ratios of hydrogen helium H-He were varied in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror central cell. Fields with azimuthal mode number m=-1 were selectively excited by a `rotating-field' antenna array located at ω/ΩH=0.8. Evidence of varied fast and slow wave absorption, including variations in the radial profiles of wave magnetic fields and plasma parameters density and diamagnetism were observed during scans of the injected gas ratio

z:row.TitlePrimary: Current drive experiments in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on RF Power in Plasmas, 19-21 Aug. 1991
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Charleston, SC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experiments in progress on the Phaedrus-T tokamak focus on effects associated with fast wave current drive at low harmonics of the cyclotron frequency, typically either 3 ΩCD or 1.5 ΩCH on axis. Areas of investigation include edge effects, directionality of wave launch, and comparison of wave absorption to numerical predictions. More general aspects of current drive, such as wave helicity effects which can be viewed as part of a complete picture of the nonlinear contributions to current drive, will be extensively studied. Early Thomson scattering data appears to indicate that RF power coupling to electrons is affected by antenna phasing. However, current drive has not yet been observed. Several innovations have also been implemented on the experiment, including insulating limiters on the Faraday shield to reduce RF-edge plasma interactions, an antenna design which reduces inductive coupling between the straps for operation at arbitrary phase, modelling of the coupled straps to allow predictive retuning on phase changes, and a two-channel transformer coupled transmitter
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-T tokamak; fast wave current drive; cyclotron frequency; edge effects; wave absorption; numerical predictions; wave helicity effects; Thomson scattering data; antenna phasing; two-channel transformer coupled transmitter

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental studies of the rotational stability of a tandem mirror with quadrupole end cells
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is demonstrated that the radial electric field in the Phaedrus Tandem Mirror [Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1984 (IAEA, Vienna, 1985), vol.2, p.265] can be altered using plasma potential control rings (PPC rings) situated at each end of the device and the azimuthal plasma rotational velocity may thus be varied. Low-frequency (ω≪ωci), low azimuthal mode number (m=-1 and m=-2) instabilities driven by E×B rotation are observed and shown to be in qualitative agreement with the theory of Freidberg and D'Ippolito [Phys. Fluids 26, 2657 (1983)], and Phillips [Phys. Fluids 27, 1783 (1984)] for the case when Phaedrus is operated as a conventional tandem mirror with minimum-|B| end cells
z:row.User2: rotational stability; tandem mirror; quadrupole end cells; radial electric field; plasma potential control rings

z:row.TitlePrimary: RF edge interactions and insulating limiters in Phaedrus-T
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on RF Power in Plasmas, 19-21 Aug. 1991
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Charleston, SC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Inductively generated RF sheaths and self-bias effects at antenna Faraday screens are at least partly responsible for the impurity influx and edge modifications often seen in RF heating experiments. Analysis of JET results has shown that the effectiveness of solutions utilized in that experiment to reduce RF impurity influxes can be explained in terms of RF sheath effects. On both JET and TFTR magnetic field-aligned Faraday shield elements, low-Z coatings, and 180° phasing of adjacent antenna straps have been effective at reducing impurities. However, alignment of Faraday shield elements is difficult, low-Z coatings do not remove the underlying causes of sputtering, and 180° phasing reduces loading resistance and is incompatible with certain RF goals, such as fast wave current drive. Here the authors show that RF generated impurity influxes in the Phaedrus-T tokamak are due to self-bias effects in the edge plasma generated by RF sheaths at the Faraday shield, and that these effects can be largely eliminated for any antenna phasing by the use of insulating limiters on the Faraday shield
z:row.User2: RF edge interactions; insulating limiters; Phaedrus-T; RF sheaths; self-bias effects; antenna Faraday screens; impurity influx; edge modifications; RF heating; low-Z coatings; sputtering; fast wave current drive; tokamak; edge plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Aperture effects on charged particles in a magnetic field
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In this paper the authors present investigations of two kinds of aperture effects on charged particles in the presence of a magnetic field. The first is an experimental study of the plasma potential profiles in front of an aperture. Plasma potential is measured with emissive probes. The interaction between the plasma and the solid wall of the aperture results in a nonuniform potential profile. Their experiments show that suitable aperture biasing can smooth the electric field in front of the aperture. The second is the transmission of electrons through a finite thickness aperture. The experimental results of the latter are compared to results of a single particle orbit model. It is shown that transmission measurements can be used to estimate the electron perpendicular energy in the magnetic field
z:row.User2: electron transmission; charged particles; magnetic field; aperture effects; plasma potential; emissive probes; solid wall; electric field; single particle orbit model

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental simulation of a gaseous divertor: measurements of neutral density inside the plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Direct measurements of the neutral density in the core of hydrogen plasma with a density of 3-4×1014 cm-3 and electron temperature of 15-20 eV in a magnetic field of 0.2 T, injected into hydrogen neutral gas at a pressure of 0.1-2 Torr are performed with plasma emission spectroscopy. The data are in agreement with the results of measured plasma decay [Phys. Fluids B 2, 837 (1990)] and can be explained by radial pressure balance between fast neutrals inside the plasma and cold background gas
z:row.User2: experimental simulation; gaseous divertor; neutral density; electron temperature; plasma emission spectroscopy; radial pressure balance; 15 to 20 eV; 0.1 to 2 torr; 0.2 T; H plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Instantaneous etch rate measurement of thin transparent films by interferometry for use in an algorithm to control a plasma etcher
z:row.TitleSecondary: Advanced Techniques for Integrated Circuit Processing, Oct 1-5 1990
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
z:row.Keyword: Films -- Etching|Plasma Devices - Control|Interferometry|Process Control|Silica|Etching - Measurements
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Int Soc for Optical Engineering, Bellingham, WA, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Clara, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A goal of our Engineering Research Center for Plasma Aided Manufacturing is to develop a feedback system to control a plasma etcher. Our system etches 1 micron thermally grown SiO2 layers using gas mixtures of CF4/CHF3/O2. Thin-film interferometry is conventionally used to measure an average etch rate; each interferometric fringe signals a change in film depth of λ/2n. Our method determines the instantaneous etch rate using data from the interferometer. The instantaneous etch rate will be used as feedback in a scheme to control the etch process by regulating the power and gas flow into the etcher. Results will be presented showing interferometric traces and analysis of the data. The status of the feedback effort will also be presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: An improved capacitive divider probe for plasma potential measurements in the Phaedrus tokamak
z:row.Keyword: electric potential|electric sensing devices|plasma probes|Tokamak devices|voltage measurement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: High bandwidth capacitive probes are useful tools for potentials measurements in the tokamak scrape off layer. An improved capacitive divider probe design with very high frequency bandwidth is shown. The gain of this system is between 0 and -8 dB for frequencies from 0.1 Hz to more than 100 MHz, with the -3 dB point at approximately 40 MHz. The probe structure, circuits, performance, and experimental results from the Phaedrus-T tokamak are given

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mode conversion analysis based on the fast wave consideration
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on RF Power in Plasmas, 19-21 Aug. 1991
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Charleston, SC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Mode conversion analysis based on the consideration of fast waves is discussed. The 4th order wave equation for fast and slow waves in the mode conversion region is reduced to the 2nd order equation for the fast wave only, and corresponding energy conversation principles are derived and compared. The energy conservation relation for the 2nd order equation includes not only absorbed power but the mode converted power as well, which gives an opportunity to separate the mode converted power. The fast wave equation can be solved as a single-pass problem and the scattering coefficients can be found. The 1-D code FAST1D for such an analysis is developed, and results for the scattering coefficients and absorbed power are presented and found to be in reasonable agreement with the 4th order code CARDS. The generalization of the proposed procedure to the global wave code FASTWA and the results obtained are shown as well
z:row.User2: mode conversion analysis; ICRF plasma heating; fast wave consideration; fast waves; 4th order wave equation; 2nd order equation; energy conversation principles; energy conservation relation; absorbed power; mode converted power; scattering coefficients; FAST1D; CARDS; global wave code; FASTWA

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the role of laboratory plasmas for space research--A case study--Alfven wave heating of a two-ion species mirror plasma
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1991 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, Jun 3-5 1991
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Williamsburg, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept of Nucl Eng & Eng Phys, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Heating by Alfven waves in multi-ion species plasmas has been identified as important in space plasmas. This problem is particularly interesting because the presence of two ions species allows mode conversion between shear Alfven and magnetosonic waves. Ion heating by ICRF (waves in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies) in a laboratory mirror geometry has been investigated in single and two ion species plasmas. Experiments were carried out in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror with a 'U' shaped magnetic field. When only a single species was present, only direct excitation was possible when the antenna frequency was below the local ion cyclotron frequency. Fields with azimuthal mode number m = -1 were selectively excited by a rotating-field antenna array located at ω/ΩH = 0.8. Evidence of varied fast and slow wave absorption, including variations in the radial profiles of wave magnetic fields and plasma parameters (density and diamagnetism), was observed during scans of the injected gas ratio. Bench heating of H plasmas with 'U' shaped fields resulted in the highest plasma parameters in Phaedrus-B.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Summary Only; Laboratory Plasmas; Alfven Waves; Mirror Plasmas

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mirror devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recent developments in mirror physics and prospects for mirror based neutron sources and a D- 3He mirror reactor are presented.
