z:row.TitlePrimary: Triple Langmuir probe measurements in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: 8th Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 6-10 May 1990
z:row.Keyword: plasma density|plasma diagnostics|plasma instability|plasma temperature|plasma toroidal confinement
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Hyannis, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Triple Langmuir probe data have been obtained in the initial phase of Phaedrus-T operation. The data were obtained during ohmic discharges of roughly 60 kA, ⟨n⟩=5×1018 m-3, Te(0)=0.5 keV, BT=0.7 T, q(a)=4 and 80 ms duration. Measurements of Te, φF, and n were made in a radial scan in the scrape-off layer of the plasma. The toroidal and poloidal positions were fixed throughout the scan. The spectra of Te, φF, and n fluctuations up to 100 kHz were also measured. One of the interesting features of these data is that m=2 oscillations detected by Mirnov coils were very pronounced in the φF and Te fluctuation spectra, but are not as evident in the n fluctuations. These data are presented and the techniques employed to get these data are discussed. Future plans to extend the maximum frequency resolution of the fluctuation measurements up to and beyond the frequency range of the ICRF power (13-18 MHz) that will be injected into Phaedrus-T are also discussed
z:row.User2: plasma density; triple Langmuir probes; electron temperature; floating potential; Phaedrus-T tokamak; scrape-off layer; fluctuations; m=2 oscillations; maximum frequency resolution; 100 kHz

z:row.TitlePrimary: Satellite probe electric field measurements and the effects of space charge
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1990 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, May 21-23 1990
z:row.Keyword: Electric Field Measurement -- Space Applications|Satellites|Plasmas--Probes|Electric Space Charge|Magnetic Field Effects
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Oakland, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. Current bias probes on satellites can in some situations photoemit much more current than they collect from nearby plasmas. Laboratory experiments were conducted to better understand the effects of electric charge accumulation, or space charge, on electric field measurements made by satellite probes in these situations. The probable magnitude of space-charge-induced errors in electric field measurements, the effects of magnetic field and plasma on space charge, and methods of interpreting satellite data to determine the extent of space charge effects were investigated.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Satellite Probes; Summary Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental simulation of a gaseous plasma collector
z:row.Keyword: arcs (electric)|plasma collision processes|plasma density|plasma guns|plasma temperature|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Hydrogen plasma with a density of 3×1014 cm-3 and electron temperature of 20 eV is injected parallel to a 0.1 T B field, into hydrogen (and helium) neutral gas at 0.1-2 Torr. This plasma is opaque to molecular hydrogen but transparent to Frank-Condon neutrals. The axial density and temperature scale length increased with decreasing gas pressure but were insensitive to plasma density and axial magnetic field strength. The plasma decay is explained by radial ion diffusion resulting from collisions with fast neutrals while the fast neutral density is determined by the radial pressure balance between fast neutrals and the cold background gas
z:row.User2: gaseous plasma collector; Frank-Condon neutrals; axial density; temperature scale length; gas pressure; plasma density; axial magnetic field strength; plasma decay; radial ion diffusion; collisions; fast neutrals; fast neutral density; radial pressure balance; cold background gas; 20 eV; 0.1 T; 0.1 to 2 Torr; H plasma; He

z:row.TitlePrimary: Particle and power balances of hot-filament discharge plasmas in a multidipole device
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper considers particle and power balances to estimate the bulk plasma potential of a hot-filament discharge plasma produced in a multidipole plasma device. The bulk plasma potential dependence on positive DC bias applied to an anode is analyzed, and the predicted characteristics of the plasma potential are compared to the experiment. It is shown that the plasma potential can be more positive or more negative than the anode bias potential. When the potential is more negative, a steady-state potential dip in front of an anode is observed using emissive probes with the zero-emission inflection point method. Conditions for the potential dip formation are discussed
z:row.User2: particle balances; power balances; hot-filament discharge plasmas; multidipole device; bulk plasma potential; positive DC bias; emissive probes; zero-emission inflection point method; potential dip formation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Very low pressure RF glow discharge plasma using multi-dipole surface magnetic fields
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1990 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, May 21-23 1990
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Oakland, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept of Nucl Eng & Eng Phys, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. It is shown that, by taking advantage of surface multidipole fields, RF glow discharges can be maintained down to pressures at least as low as 2 × 10-5 torr. Large effective electrode separation and good plasma uniformity can be achieved by making use of surface multidipole magnetic fields. Only one conventional electrode was used. Two different types of RF powered electrodes were explored: a conventional plate with a diameter of 15 cm and a rod with a diameter of 1.3 cm. The powered electrode was located sufficiently far from the magnets that the magnetic field could be ignored. The line cusps replace the other electrode. Line cusps fully surround a 20-liter plasma. Experiments employed argon plasmas with 13.56-MHz RF power. A second grounded electrode was also employed. This plate differed from the powered electrode in that it was located within the surface magnetic field. Adjustment of the separation of this plate from the magnet plane permits continuous variation of the maximum surface magnetic field seen by plasma and the effective loss area at the electrode. It was found that the plasma potential can be continuously varied by changing the position of the grounded plate and that the surface magnetic field is effective in improving plasma confinement at pressures at least as high as 10-3 torr.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: RF Discharges; Summary Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: RF discharge with multidipole surface magnetic confinement for low pressure plasma etching
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1990 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, May 21-23 1990
z:row.Keyword: Semiconductor Materials -- Etching|Plasma Devices|Plasmas--Confinement|Electric Discharges|Magnetic Fields
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Oakland, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. The development of a plasma source for semiconductor etching which employs permanent magnet multidipole fields is discussed. RF power at 13.56 MHz is applied to a 6-in.-diameter disk electrode inside the magnet bucket. Langmuir probe measurements of plasma density and electron temperatures in argon have been performed over operating parameters ranging from 10-5 torr to 50 mtorr and up to 500 W of RF power. Measurements of self-bias on the powered electrode and RF fluctuations of the floating potential were also obtained for this set of parameters. Preliminary etching results of Si with an Al mask at 3 × 10-4 torr in a CF4/02 gas mixture and 100 W of RF power show anisotropic etch profiles, but low etch rates and some degree of mask erosion. For these conditions in argon, plasma densities of about 7 × 109 cm-3 were observed. Higher densities are needed for higher etch rates, and this can be obtained by either increasing the power level or increasing the pressure. However, the electrode self-bias scales almost linearly with power; thus, increasing the power level can lead to unacceptably high ion bombardment energies. Increasing the operating pressure may help to some degree, but it may be necessary to power the system in a triode arrangement in order to achieve suitable etching conditions.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: RF Discharges; Langmuir Probes; Summary Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: ICRF-edge plasma investigations in Phaedrus-B
z:row.TitleSecondary: IAEA Technical Committee Meeting on ICRH/Edge Physics, 2-5 Oct. 1989
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|magnetic mirrors|plasma instability|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma simulation|plasma-wall interactions
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Garching, West Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors describe experiments which investigate the characteristics of a test ICRF coupler. The RF magnetic fields near the antenna are measured in vacuum and in plasma. Results are modelled using the code ANTENA in plasma; details of the vacuum fields are modelled with the code ARGUS. For the plasma experiments, the antenna is mounted in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. ICRF modification of the edge plasma potential at the Faraday shield and coupling to electrostatic modes are also investigated
z:row.User2: ICRF-edge plasma investigations; Phaedrus-B; test ICRF coupler; RF magnetic fields; antenna; vacuum; code; ANTENA; ARGUS; central cell; tandem mirror; Faraday shield; electrostatic modes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mode conversion between Alfven wave eigenmodes in axially inhomogeneous two-ion-species plasmas
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|magnetic mirrors|magnetohydrodynamic waves|plasma probes|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The uniform cylindrical plasma model of Litwin and Hershkowitz [Phys. Fluids 30, 1323 (1987)] is shown to predict mode conversion between the lowest radial order m=+1 fast magnetosonic surface and slow ion-cyclotron global eigenmodes of the Alfven wave at the light-ion species Alfven resonance of a cold two-ion plasma. A hydrogen (h)-deuterium (d) plasma is examined in experiments. The fast mode is efficiently excited by a rotating field antenna array at ω~Ωh in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror [Phys. Rev. Lett. 51, 1955 (1983)]. Radially scanned magnetic probes observe the propagating eigenmode wave fields within a shallow central cell magnetic gradient in which the conversion zone is axially localized according to nd/nh. A low radial-order slow ion-cyclotron mode, observed in the vicinity of the conversion zone, gives evidence for the predicted mode conversion
z:row.User2: fast magnetosonic surface eigenmodes; radially scanned magnetic probes; axially localised zone; Alfven wave eigenmodes; axially inhomogeneous two-ion-species plasmas; uniform cylindrical plasma model; mode conversion; slow ion-cyclotron global eigenmodes; cold two-ion plasma; fast mode; rotating field antenna array; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; propagating eigenmode wave fields; shallow central cell magnetic gradient; conversion zone; low radial-order slow ion-cyclotron mode; D-H plasma

z:row.TitleSecondary: 8th Topical Conference on Radio-Frequency Power in Plasmas, 1-3 May 1989
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Irvine, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: RF B fields are measured near the Faraday shield of a model loop antenna in a vacuum and in the presence of a plasma. The axisymmetric plasma is produced in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. Results are found to be in good agreement with the predictions of the code ANTENA

z:row.TitlePrimary: Probe technique for direct measurement of temporal variation of electron temperature
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science 1989, May 22-24 1989
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Buffalo, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A technique for making direct measurements of electron temperature oscillations in a plasma is discussed. The technique uses the relationship between the floating potential, Vf, and the plasma potential, Vp, for a Maxwellian distribution of electrons with temperature Te, Vp = Vf + (Te/e)ln(mi/ 0.64 πme)1/2. The plasma potential and floating potential oscillations are measured directly, and the temperature oscillation is inferred through this relationship. The technique uses a pair of identical cylindrical probes, each consisting of a tungsten filament stretched between two external leads. One of the probes is operated as an emissive probe, so that it floats near the plasma potential, while the other probe, which is not emitting, is at the floating potential. The difference of these two potentials is monitored with a differential amplifier, giving a signal that is proportional to the electron temperature. Initial measurements were made with argon in a hot-filament discharge plasma confined in a multidipole magnetic field. A perturbation that produced electron temperature variations was introduced by inserting an externally biased plate into the plasmas. With the plate biased DC or with a slowly varying voltage, independent measurements of Vp, Vf, and Te were made from the I-V characteristic of a Langmuir probe. By comparison with the direct temperature measurement, both the accuracy of the Vp-Vf measurement and its relation to the electron temperature were evaluated.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Electron Temperature; Plasma Potential; Langmuir Probe; Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of electromagnetic waves in Phaedrus-B: bench-mark test of ANTENA wave field calculations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is shown that the predictions of a numerical code (ANTENA) and the data of wave field measurements in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror are consistent (±25%) for right-handed (B&oarr;-) wave fields and less so (±40%) for left-handed (B&oarr;+) wave fields in the plasma core, and that they disagree for B&oarr;+ fields near the column edge. Shorting out or reduction of the wave azimuthal electric fields by limiters is the probable cause of this discrepancy. The ICRF fluctuating wave B&oarr; fields are shown as |B&oarr;| contour maps in the r-z plane, where the B&oarr;+ data peak at a smaller radius than predicted. The waves are characterized by different dominant axial wave numbers for the left- and right-handed circularly polarized fields
z:row.User2: EM wave measurements; bench-mark test; ANTENA; wave field calculations; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; ICRF

z:row.TitlePrimary: Particle and power balances of hot-filament discharge plasmas in a multi-dipole device in the presence of a positively biased electrode
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science 1989, May 22-24 1989
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Buffalo, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The plasma potential is typically assumed to float above an anode potential by an amount that is a few times the electron temperature (Te/e). The difference between the plasma potential and the anode potential can be estimated by considering the particle production and loss. However, it has been reported experimentally that the plasma potential of a steady-state plasma can be more negative than the anode potential with a potential dip (approximately Te/e) in front of the anode. Particle and power balances have been carried out to estimate the bulk plasma potential of a hot-filament discharge plasma produced in a multidipole plasma device. The bulk plasma potential dependence on the positive DC bias applied to the anode is analyzed, and the predicted characteristics of the plasma potential dependence are compared to the experimental results. A steady-state potential dip in front of the anode has been experimentally observed using emissive probes with the zero emission inflection point method, and the conditions for the potential dip formation have been derived.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Electron Temperature; Power Balances; Multidipole Plasma Devices; Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of sheath potential in an RF inductive discharge plasma with a DC magnetic field
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science 1989, May 22-24 1989
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Buffalo, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It has been claimed that in the presence of an oblique magnetic field, the sheath exhibits a double structure consisting of an electrostatic sheath the order of a Debye length and a magnetic sheath the order of the ion gyroradius evaluated at the ion sound speed. Measurements of sheath potential, occurring in front of negatively or positively biased plate, have been performed in the presence of an external DC magnetic field with orientations nearly parallel or perpendicular to the plate in an electrodeless RF induction plasma in a multidipole device. This source operates at frequencies ranging from approximately 1 MHz to approximately 20 MHz, depending on the tuned resonance frequency, and at a neutral gas pressure gt;5 × 10-5 torr. It has been operated with DC magnetic fields up to approximately 100 G, and a strong electron cyclotron resonance effect has been observed. Plasmas produced at low neutral pressure ( torr. It has been operated with DC magnetic fields up to approximately 100 G, and a strong electron cyclotron resonance effect has been observed. Plasmas produced at low neutral pressure (-3 torr) have good spatial uniformity independently of magnetic field direction.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of the ponderomotive force including sideband mode coupling effects and damping rates
z:row.Keyword: plasma diagnostics|plasma instability|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Measurements of the interactions of waves in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies (ICRF) with flute interchange modes are presented. Interactions between the applied l=1 radio frequency (RF) wave and an m=-1 flute mode give rise to sidebands above and below the RF frequency with mode numbers of l=0 and l=+2, respectively. The contribution of the sideband terms to stability are shown to cancel 40% of the direct ponderomotive contribution. This is less than the 90% predicted by theory [Phys. Fluids 30, 148 (1987)] for an applied l=+1 RF wave above the ion cyclotron frequency with a large separation between the plasma and the vacuum vessel. Measurements of the linear growth and damping rate of the flute instability in the presence of RF are in good agreement with that calculated by considering only the curvature-driven instability and the ponderomotive force. The growth rate of the magnetohydrodynamic mode is consistent with the primary force acting on the plasma being the curvature force. This method allows a determination of the net stabilizing force on the plasma
z:row.User2: RF wave; heating; ponderomotive force; sideband mode coupling effects; damping rates; waves; ion cyclotron range of frequencies; flute interchange modes; mode numbers; vacuum vessel; linear growth; curvature-driven instability; magnetohydrodynamic mode; net stabilizing force

z:row.TitlePrimary: Feedback control of a polymer producing glow discharge plasma
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science 1989, May 22-24 1989
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Buffalo, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Glow discharges are produced in a conventional parallel-plate device using either propylene or argon. The propylene discharge differs from the argon discharge in that polymers are continuously deposited at the plasma boundaries. Discharges with plasma densities of approximately 109 cm-3, Te congruent 3 eV are produced at neutral pressures of approximately 300 mtorr at RF frequencies of approximately 100 kHz. The device consists of two parallel plates (diameter = 7.5 cm, separation approximately 5 cm). Langmuir probe current-voltage (I-V) characteristics are monitored with a heated mesh probe. A PC monitors the I-V characteristic every 30 s and adjusts the gain of the glow discharge RF amplifier to maintain a desired I-V characteristic as wall conditions, etc. change.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radial ion diffusion induced by cyclotron resonance heating at the thermal barrier region in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science 1989, May 22-24 1989
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Buffalo, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experiments with and without ion cyclotron resonance (1.275 MHz, fundamental ion cyclotron frequency of hydrogen plasma) at the thermal-barrier region have been carried out by varying the thermal-barrier magnetic field strength. Radial density profiles, potential profiles, and currents have been measured, as well as the fueling at the thermal-barrier region. The density at the plasma edge increased and the potential at the plasma edge decreased as the B field was decreased to bring the resonance into the thermal-barrier cell in both a balanced and imbalanced gas-puffing case. The data indicated that a possible mechanism is that ions can escape from the confinement region along the open resonance surface (the same as the mod-B surfaces) because the turning point of the trapped ions has a tendency to center on mod-B surfaces. An increasing potential observed in the present experiments in the edge region of the plasma with increasing B field may be related to the higher degree of fluctuation of radial current to the collector.

z:row.User2: Phaedrus-B Tandem Mirror; Ion Cyclotron Resonance; Cyclotron Resonance Heating; Thermal Barrier; Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radio-frequency wave interchange stability experiments below the ion cyclotron frequency
z:row.Keyword: electromagnetic wave propagation in plasma|magnetic mirrors|magnetohydrodynamic waves|plasma diagnostics|plasma instability|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It has been demonstrated in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror [Phys. Fluids 31, 714 (1988)] that radio-frequency (RF) waves applied below the ion cyclotron frequency (ω/Ωi≈0.75) can stabilize a mirror plasma against the interchange instability. Results presented here demonstrate stabilization over a range of frequencies (0.65⩽ω/Ωi⩽0.8) with the mMHD=-1 instability stabilized and higher-order (|mMHD|⩾2) low-amplitude modes present. Radial profiles of the RF magnetic fields at a number of axial locations as well as parallel wavenumber measurements indicate mrf=-1 slow shear Alfven wave excitation over this frequency range. Measurements at frequencies below 0.75 Ωi indicate attenuation of RF waves by gas baffles and a gas box

z:row.TitlePrimary: The bispectrum and three-wave coupling between fast magnetosonic waves and interchange modes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The bispectrum is used to demonstrate that wave-wave coupling occurs when ponderomotive forces due to wave fields in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies are used to stabilize a magnetized plasma column against magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) interchange instabilities. The three waves that interact resonantly are an applied wave, a MHD wave, and the nonlinearly coupled sideband wave. The net ponderomotive forces contain partially canceling and augmenting contributions from each induced sideband field

z:row.TitlePrimary: Whistler-mode electron cyclotron emission from the Phaedrus-B end cell
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering and Engineering Physics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Measurements of whistler-mode electron-cyclotron emission made in the Phaedrus-B tandem-mirror end cell are described. The receiving horn was located on the axis of the machine just outboard of the end cell. Under normal conditions, the signal had a component which was identified as blackbody emission, and an electron temperature was obtained which was in good agreement with electron end loss-energy-analyzer data. In addition, the signal contained short bursts of unknown origin. Significant heating of the electrons due to end-cell ion-cyclotron frequency range (ICRF) was seen. Comparison of end loss and Thomson scattering data shows that emission from hotter edge electrons is responsible for a large part of the total signal.

z:row.Abstract: RF heating experiments in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror have utilized a rotating field antenna set to excite m=-1 cylindrical eigenmodes for hydrogen cyclotron resonance heating at a magnetic beach. Recent investigations have examined modifications to this heating imposed by the addition of deuterium or helium ion species. In addition to nearly 50% increases in Ti, the authors have observed evolution of the radial heating profiles with nM/nH (M=D or He). In particular, they discuss the correspondence of their observations with the predicted variations with nM/nH in the antenna-wave coupling to the slow ion-cyclotron global and fast magnetosonic surface wave eigenmodes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Three step double layers in the laboratory
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new class of stationary double layer structure, with three or more distinct steps, is demonstrated in the laboratory. A large monotonic potential increase results from a series of smaller double layers (each with eΔφ/Te~1-3). In many respects, these double layer structures resemble those inferred from satellite measurements of auroral double layers. This new class of double layer appears to depend on turbulence for its existence and to be a hybrid structure, intermediate between anomalous resistivity and BGK double layers

z:row.Abstract: The Phaedrus-B tandem mirror has made use of ICRF to achieve large increases in central cell density, strong axial plugging, and thermal barrier potential dips. Thermal barrier potential dips are produced without neutral beams or energetic electrons. Plasma parameters are improved by central cell antenna phasing and/or excitation by end cell antennas of beach RF which is resonant in the central cell

z:row.TitlePrimary: Multiple valued floating potentials of Langmuir probes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is shown that Langmuir probes can have three different floating potentials in plasmas produced by a hot filament discharge in a multi-dipole device when the primary and secondary electron currents are comparable. The measured floating potential depends on the probe's initial condition-the most negative and the least negative potentials are found to be stable and the in-between value is found to be unstable. Results are compared to a simple theoretical model

z:row.TitleSecondary: 34th National Symposium of the American Vacuum Society, 2-6 Nov. 1987

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recently developed plasma potential diagnostic techniques which employ emissive probes are discussed. Using these techniques it is shown that it is possible to determine the plasma potential in plasma densities of 4 to 1013 cm-3, neutral pressures of , neutral pressures of -6 to 1 Torr, ion temperature ranging from 0.1 eV to 1 keV, and electron temperature from 0.1 to 150 eV. The techniques include measurements of the inflection point of the probe's I-V characteristic in the limit of zero electron emission, differential emissive probes in which a feedback circuit compares two probes with different emission, self-emissive probes in which plasma bombardment provides the probe heating, secondary emissive capacitive probes, for which secondary electron emission coefficients are greater than 1.0, and current biased probes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Temporal evolution of collisionless sheaths
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors have performed experimental measurements to determine the temporal evolution of Langmuir sheaths near an electrode to which a negative step bias is applied in a collisionless argon plasma. The plasma was produced by a hot-filament discharge in a multidipole device. Plasma potential data were obtained using emissive probes with two different techniques: time resolved sampling and time averaged techniques. The sheath is found to initially form close to the electrode, to extend to a maximum separation, and to contract to a steady-state value. The time scale required to reach a steady state is close to the time scale of the presheath relaxation. Characteristics of sheaths in RF plasmas are also measured using a parallel-plate plasma capacitor. It is observed that the plasma potential profile has significant variation with frequency, even for frequencies as low as 1 kHz which are far below the ion plasma frequency (~1 MHz)
z:row.User2: collisionless sheaths; Langmuir sheaths; electrode; hot-filament discharge; multidipole device; time resolved sampling; time averaged techniques; RF plasmas; Ar plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radial transport in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1988. Proceedings of the Twelfth International Conference Held by the International Atomic Energy Agency, 12-19 Oct. 1988
z:row.TitleTertiary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1988. Proceedings of the Twelfth International Conference Held by the International Atomic Energy Agency
z:row.Keyword: magnetic traps|plasma devices|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma transport processes
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Nice, France
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Application of ICRF in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror end cells can result in increases in central cell plasma density by as much as a factor of three. Central cell peak densities of about 6×1012 cm-3 have been achieved along with thermal barrier-like axial density and potential profiles. Recent analysis of the data shows that an improvement in the plasma confinement occurs in both the radial and axial directions. In the core plasma, the density rise results from axial plugging; in the edge, radial loss is reduced. Detailed measurements of the potential structures and the electron end loss indicate that RF heating of electrons parallel to the magnetic field plays a dominant role in controlling the radial, as well as the axial, potential profiles. The radial potential profile has been measured to be hollow. Both electron and ion diffusion coefficients either remain the same or increase when end cell RF systems are operated. Radial potential trapping of ions in the plasma is the reason for the increase in radial confinement. Azimuthally asymmetric potential profiles have been measured in the thermal barriers, consistent with enhanced radial loss or `pumping' in this region. In addition, the electron end loss is measured to be azimuthally asymmetric. While the diffusion of the ions and the electrons in the entire plasma column is tied to the azimuthal asymmetries in the potentials, the density increases are correlated with the radial ion potential well
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-B tandem mirror end cells; central cell plasma density; thermal barrier-like axial density; potential profiles; plasma confinement; core plasma; density; axial plugging; radial loss; electron end loss; RF heating; ion diffusion coefficients; azimuthal asymmetries; radial ion potential well

z:row.Abstract: Rotating field antennas are used to achieve ponderomotive stability of interchange modes at RF frequencies ω below the ion cyclotron frequency Ωi, and measurements are made of mode conversion associated with the non-uniform axisymmetric mirror field. By rapidly changing the plasma's MHD stability during a discharge through an abrupt change in the phasing of antennas separated by 1 m, it is found that at ω/Ωi=1.25 the sideband modes reduce the stabilizing ponderomotive force by 40%. The linear damping rate associated with the ponderomotive stabilization is measured and found to agree with theory. Recent experiments measure the three components of the ICRF B fields near a model Faraday shielded ICRF antenna placed in the central cell

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The two-dimensional plasma potential measurements are given of a space-charge dominated double sheath near a hot cathode. Laboratory data show that a virtual cathode is a self-consistent solution only for a transient cathode-plasma system. Slow charge exchange ions get trapped in the potential dip that forms the virtual cathode and eventually destroy it

z:row.TitlePrimary: Interchange stabilization of a mirror plasma using radio-frequency waves below the ion cyclotron frequency
z:row.Keyword: electromagnetic wave propagation in plasma|magnetic mirrors|plasma instability|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is demonstrated that radio-frequency (RF) waves applied below the ion cyclotron frequency (ω/Ωi≈0.75) can stabilize a mirror plasma against the interchange instability. A set of phased antennas in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror central cell [Phys. Rev. Lett., vol.59, p.206 (1987)] is used to select the RF azimuthal mode number (m). When the m =-1 mode is selected, the ponderomotive force from the left-hand polarized wave fields is sufficient to stabilize the plasma. Measurements of the RF mode number and of the wave polarization indicate strong excitation of m =-1 modes with much of the wave having a left-hand polarization

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The current-voltage characteristics of Langmuir probes in rf glow discharges can be misinterpreted by the effects of rf time averaging, ionization near a probe, and expansion of the probe sheath. This paper presents a new Langmuir probe technique which can be used to determine the plasma parameters in rf glow discharges. Simple expressions for the time averaged 1-V characteristics are derived for the cases of fully sinusoidal and partially rectified plasma potential waveforms. Examples of corresponding 1-V characteristics obtained from argon rf glow discharges are also illustrated.

z:row.TitlePrimary: ICRF produced thermal barriers in a three-cell axisymmetric tandem mirror
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A thermal barrier plasma potential structure in a three-cell axisymmetric tandem mirror has been produced using only ion cyclotron range of frequencies (ICRF), with a central cell density of up to 1013 cm-3 and a central cell ion temperature of approximately 40 ev. Thermal barrier like potential dips occurred in the region of a magnetic field gradient, at a magnetic beach of a slow wave launched in the end cell. The barrier formation is a result of a combination of radiofrequency trapping, radiofrequency enhanced potentials and μ Del B forces. The barrier pumping is consistent with μ Del B forces and Eθ×B drifts.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Characteristics of plasma produced by an RF induction discharge

z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental studies of an electrodeless RF induction plasma generator have been performed, using a multidipole device. This source uses a single-turn loop antenna made out of an enamel-coated copper strip and operates at frequencies ranging from approximately 1 MHz to approximately 20 MHz, depending on the tuned resonance frequency, and at neutral gas pressure >=5 × 10-5 torr. It has been operated with several different type of gases and their mixtures (Ar, N2, H2, and CH4). Preliminary results have shown that the plasma density is strongly dependent on RF power level and the electron temperature is strongly dependent on neutral gas pressure. The efficiency of RF power coupling to the plasma by the antenna is approximately 30%.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Stairstep double layers
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science - 1988, Jun 6-8 1988
z:row.Keyword: Plasmas -- Turbulence|Space Research|Electrons|Ions|Mathematical Techniques--Boundary Value Problems
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering & Engineering Physics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A novel double-layer space-plasma structure with two or more steps has been demonstrated in the laboratory. It is argued that the structure is a hybrid structure in which BGK-like double-layer steps, which depend on the ion and electron distribution functions at the edge of the individual steps, are combined with low- and high-frequency turbulence (at 20 kHz and 50 MHz) to produce the distribution functions. The stairstep double layers are not BGK structures in the sense that the potentials of the steps are not directly determined by the boundary conditions. The stairstep double layers have been produced in a triple plasma device in which parameters have been adjusted so that ionization can not be responsible for their existence. They are stable structures in the sense that their overall shape remains unchanged over many days, but significant spatial variation is found in both low- and high-frequency noise. They resemble striations and other double-layer-like structures associated with ionization. In many respects, they resemble structures inferred from satellite measurements of auroral double layers.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Stairstep Double Layers; Distribution Functions; Auroral Double Layers; Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: ICRF heating with mode control provided by a rotating field antenna
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A rotating field antenna set - a pair of two closely spaced dual half-turn antennas - is used to tailor the azimuthal spectrum of the antenna field. It is demonstrated that the azimuthal mode of ICRF waves can be controlled by proper phasing of the antenna set. Ion heating is shown to be strongly dependent on the azimuthal mode number. When the antenna set is operated in the m= -1 (left rotating) mode, the m= -1 modifiesd ion cyclotron wave is selectively excited, resulting in efficient ion heating.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radial transport modification in Phaedrus-B tandem mirror using floating end rings
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science - 1988, Jun 6-8 1988

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experiments with grounded end rings and floating end rings have been carried out in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. It has been demonstrated that floating the end rings modifies the central cell density. This modification in density is believed to be the result of changes in axial and radial transport. Radial potential profile measurements have been made in the central cell using self-emissive probes. These measurements indicate that the floating end rings reduce the overall central-cell plasma potential. In addition, the relative plasma potential (compared to the on-axis value) decreases at large radii when the end rings are floated.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Compressional Alfven waves in a B field gradient
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science - 1988, Jun 6-8 1988

z:row.Abstract: In the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror experiment (ne approx. 1012-1013 cm-3, B0 approx. 1000 G, Te approx. Ti approx. 40-100 eV), compressional and torsional Alfven waves that can heat the plasma can be excited. Detailed experimental diagnostics can be used to display the wave characteristics in the uniform and nonuniform regions of the plasma. Understanding of these types of waves is hampered by the nonuniformity in the background plasma and magnetic mirror field, which not only couples the fast and slow modes, but also makes theory very difficult. Electromagnetic and electrostatic wave fields have been measured with B-dot probes and capacitive emissive probes in a full two-dimensional plane. The spatial dependence of the wave amplitudes, phases and polarization indicate that the fast wave magnetic fields are localized away from the mirror region with large electrostatic fluctuations and polarization change in the mirror region. The possibility that wave energy could either be mode converted, reflected or both has been investigated.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Alfven Waves; Tandem Mirrors; Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: RF field measurements in the vicinity of an ICRF antenna
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science - 1988, Jun 6-8 1988
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Measurements of the RF fields near an ICRF antenna installed in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror have been made, both in vacuum and in the presence of plasma (ne 13 cm-3, Te i < 100 eV). The antenna is a Faraday shielded partial (60°) turn loop. The front surface of the Faraday shield is composed of cylindrical elements in an arrangement similar to the Faraday shield design used on the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor. The test is run at relatively low power levels (<40 kW), in the 3.5-10-MHz frequency range. Two other ICRF systems in the Phaedrus-B central cell sustain and heat the plasma at the 400-kW level. The vacuum field measurements have been compared with the predictions of the ARGUS code, which models details of the Faraday shield structure. Fields in the plasma have been modeled by the ANTENA code of Brian McVey. Particle currents collected by the Faraday shield during plasma operation have also been observed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: RF Fields; Phaedrus-B Tandem Mirror; Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor; Ion Cyclotron Resonance Frequencies (ICRF); Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Stabilization of MHD modes in an axisymmetric magnetic mirror by applied RF waves and initial results of Phaedrus-B
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eleventh IAEA International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 13-20 Nov. 1986
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kyoto, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Phaedrus was operated as a three-cell axisymmetric tandem mirror with dual half-turn end cell antennas at the end cell midplanes. The device was converted to a five-cell tandem mirror (Phaedrus-B) with quadrupole end cells by adding choke coils at the ends of the central cell and dual half-turn antennas throughout the device. The axisymmetric Phaedrus operation achieved enhanced axial plugging which improved the central cell density to n=1×1013 cm-3, the peak plasma beta to 13% and nτp to 3×1010 cm-3. The MHD stability was enhanced by the radial ponderomotive force using ICRF at 1.3, 1.7 and 4 Ωi. A kinetic theory of RF stabilization has been developed which includes the effects of RF sideband modes. The results suggest that RF far fields `lean' on the device walls and RF near fields `lean' on the antennas. The results were found to be sensitive to the antenna kz spectrum. Thermal barrier potential dips were identified without active barrier pumping. Low frequency fluctuations were found to be sensitive to the phasing of the central cell antennas. Plugging was enhanced by the presence of end cell RF which was resonant only in the central cell
z:row.User2: MHD modes; axisymmetric magnetic mirror; RF waves; three-cell; dual half-turn end cell antennas; five-cell; choke coils; central cell density; peak plasma beta; radial ponderomotive force

z:row.TitlePrimary: Electrostatic end plugging accompanied by a central-cell density increase in an axisymmetric tandem mirror
z:row.Keyword: magnetic mirrors|plasma collision processes|plasma density|plasma heating|plasma temperature|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electrostatic end plugging is observed in a completely axisymmetric, three cell tandem mirror under conditions where the central-cell plasma density is always larger than the end-cell density. A factor of 4 increase in the central-cell density, to a maximum of 1.2×1013 cm-3 with simultaneous plasma beta of 13%, occurs upon application of the end plugging potential. Ion confining potentials of 25 V and 80 V at the two ends of the device, respectively, result in a factor of 2.5 increase in the axial confinement time for Tic=40 eV in agreement with the collisional flow model for ion confinement. The non-Boltzmann ion confining potential is caused by electron heating in the end cells by RF near the ion-cyclotron frequency. The initial central-cell density rise is caused by an increase in the ionization rate that occurs because of an increase in the electron temperature. The density remains high throughout the end-cell heating pulse as a result of increased particle confinement time. There is no nonambipolar radial ion loss in the core plasma (r⩽16 cm) but inward radial transport of ions is observed at a rate consistent with ion-neutral collisions and a radial electric field in the negative radial direction. Steady-state thermal-barrier-like potential dips that are in agreement with the Boltzmann model for potentials are observed in the transitions between the central cell and the end cells
z:row.User2: electrostatic end plugging; ion confining potentials; nonBoltzmann potential; central-cell density; axisymmetric tandem mirror; plasma beta; axial confinement time; collisional flow model; ion confinement; electron heating; ion-cyclotron frequency; ionization rate; electron temperature; density; particle confinement time; core plasma; radial transport; ion-neutral collisions; radial electric field; negative radial direction; thermal-barrier-like potential dips; Boltzmann model; 25 V; 80 V

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of parallel electric fields on the ponderomotive stabilization of MHD instabilities
z:row.TitleSecondary: Applications of Radio-Frequency Power Plasmas - Seventh Topical Conference, 4-6 May 1987
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kissimmee, FL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The contribution of the wave electric field component E∥, parallel to the magnetic field, to the ponderomotive stabilization of curvature driven instabilities is evaluated and compared to the transverse component contribution. For the experimental density range, in which the stability is primarily determined by the m=1 magnetosonic wave, this contribution is found to be dominant and stabilizing when the electron temperature is neglected. For sufficiently high electron temperatures the dominant fast wave is found to be axially evanescent. In the same limit, E∥ becomes radially oscillating. It is concluded that the increased electron temperature near the plasma surface reduces the magnitude of ponderomotive effects
z:row.User2: axially evanescent fast wave; radial oscillation; parallel electric fields; ponderomotive stabilization; MHD instabilities; wave electric field component; curvature driven instabilities; transverse component; density; magnetosonic wave; electron temperature; electron temperature; ponderomotive effects

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mode control with phased antenna arrays in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3), 1-3 June 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two phased antenna configurations for inertial-confinement RF (ICRF) heating have been studied in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. In the first configuration, a pair of dual half-turn ICRF antennas spaced 1 m apart are driven with variable relative phase. Calculations of the ponderomotive force due to the radial electric fields of the eigenmode have shown that ponderomotive effects are sufficient to stabilize the plasma against curvature-driven MHD instabilities in this case, in good agreement with observations. In the second configuration, a pair of dual half-turn ICRF antennas spaced 7.5 cm apart are driven with variable relative phase in a rotating field arrangement. Ion heating efficiency and slow magnetosonic wave excitation have been investigated as a function of the relative antenna phasing for this configuration
z:row.User2: phased antenna arrays; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; configurations; inertial-confinement RF; dual half-turn ICRF antennas; variable relative phase; ponderomotive force; eigenmode; curvature-driven MHD instabilities; rotating field arrangement; slow magnetosonic wave excitation; 7.5 cm

z:row.TitlePrimary: Secondary electron emission-capacitive probes for plasma potential measurements in plasmas with hot electrons
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is shown that a secondary electron emission-capacitive probe can determine the plasma potential when Te⩾50 eV. The probe is wideband (1 Hz to greater than 20 MHz) and relatively simple to operate. The Phaedrus-B tandem mirror plasma where Te~40-60 eV and n≃5×1012 cm-3 is used to verify this technique
z:row.User2: plasma potential; hot electrons; secondary electron emission-capacitive probe; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: The use of secondary emissive capacitive probes to determine plasma potential-a new diagnostic technique
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3), 1-3 June 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors discuss a plasma potential diagnostic technique that is suitable for use in plasmas in which the electron temperature is greater than 40-50 eV. The technique is based on secondary electron emission by plasma electrons. This secondary-emission capacitive probe is much less sensitive to electron-temperature variations than conventional nonemitting floating probes
z:row.User2: secondary emissive capacitive probes; plasma potential; diagnostic technique; electron temperature; secondary electron emission; plasma electrons

z:row.TitlePrimary: Vacuum and sheath potential measurements with current biased emissive probes
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3), 1-3 June 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Data have been obtained that show that an electron-emitting (emissive) probe with proper current bias can make accurate vacuum potential measurements and sheath potential measurements. It has been found that these probes are more accurate and have better time response than zero-current-biased (floating) emissive probes. The proper current bias for accurate vacuum potential measurements has been determined
z:row.User2: current biased emissive probes; vacuum potential measurements; sheath potential measurements; current bias

z:row.TitlePrimary: MODE CONTROL WITH PHASED ANTENNA ARRAYS IN THE PHAEDRUS-B TANDEM MIRROR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record - Abstracts: 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science.
z:row.Keyword: PLASMAS -- Heating|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions|ANTENNAS - Phased Arrays
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two phased antenna configurations for inertial-confinement RF (ICRF) heating have been studied in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror. In the first configuration, a pair of dual half-turn ICRF antennas space 1 m apart are driven with variable relative phase. Calculations of the ponderomotive force due to the radial electric fields of the eigenmode have shown that ponderomotive effects are sufficient to stabilize the plasma against curvature-driven MHD instabilities in this case, in good agreement with observations. In the second configuration, a pair of dual half-turn ICRF antennas spaced 7. 5 cm apart are driven with variable relative phase in a rotating field arrangement. Ion heating efficiency and slow magnetosonic wave excitation have been investigated as a function of the relative antenna phasing for this configuration.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Interchange stabilization of an axisymmetric single cell mirror using high-frequency electric fields
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Stabilization of interchange instabilities in the Phaedrus tandem mirror [Phys. Rev. Lett. 51, 1955 (1983)] through the use of externally applied RF at a single frequency is demonstrated over a wide range of frequency (1.03Ωii). Here RF stabilized plasmas are reported with ion temperature up to 550 eV and beta up to 8%. Calculations of the RF electric fields show that the dominant mode is the m=+1 fast wave. When the RF frequency is near Ωi the calculated ponderomotive forces on ions and electrons are shown to be comparable. For ω>1.3Ωi it is shown that the force acts primarily on electrons. Stable plasmas are only achieved when the net radial ponderomotive force is calculated to be stabilizing and comparable to the curvature force. Results are also reported for RF applied simultaneously at two frequencies, one which is stabilizing and one which is destabilizing. Abrupt changes in stability are observed as the RF power is increased whenever one of the RF frequencies is effective at plasma heating
z:row.User2: stabilisation; stabilising effect; destabilising effect; axisymmetric single cell mirror; high-frequency electric fields; interchange instabilities; Phaedrus tandem mirror; RF stabilized plasmas; ion temperature; dominant mode; fast wave; ponderomotive forces; curvature force; plasma heating; 550 eV

z:row.TitlePrimary: MEASUREMENTS OF TRANSIENT SHEATHS AND RF AFFECTED PLASMA POTENTIAL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record - Abstracts: 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science.
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental measurements of the transient sheath near an electrode with a sudden negative bias in a collisionless argon plasma are discussed. The sheath is found to start as a matrix sheath, and then expand to have a greater extent than Child-Langmuir sheath, and finally contracts to a Child-Langmuir sheath. RF effects have been measured in a parallel plasma capacitor. The results show that from dc up to 500 kHz the plasma potential profiles vary significantly. To avoid RF related complications in plasma production, a hot-filament discharge plasma in a multidiode device has been used.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TRANSIENT SHEATHS; COLLISIONLESS ARGON PLASMA; RF EFFECTS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Rarefaction shock in the near wake
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Laboratory experiments and fluid theory find a stationary rarefaction shock in the near wake of an electrically grounded obstacle placed in a steady state, supersonic plasma flow. The shock is only found when two electron temperatures, differing by at least an order of magnitude, are present. These shocks are analogous to rarefaction shocks in plasma free expansions
z:row.User2: fluid theory; stationary rarefaction shock; near wake; electrically grounded obstacle; supersonic plasma flow; electron temperatures

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effect of variable eigenmode excitation on RF stabilization of a mirror plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is shown that wave eigenmode fields can provide RF stabilization of the interchange instability. The excitation level of an m=+1 fast magnetosonic wave is controlled by tailoring of the k∥ spectrum of an axial ion-cyclotron radio-frequency antenna array in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror system. When the k∥ spectrum is chosen to excite the wave strongly, density-fluctuation levels in the plasma are greatly reduced
z:row.User2: variable eigenmode excitation; RF stabilization; mirror plasma; wave eigenmode fields; interchange instability; excitation level; m=+1 fast magnetosonic wave; axial ion-cyclotron radio-frequency antenna array; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror system

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of transient sheaths and RF affected plasma potential
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3), 1-3 June 1987

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental measurements of the transient sheath near an electrode with a sudden negative bias in a collisionless argon plasma are discussed. The sheath is found to start as a matrix sheath, and then expand to have a greater extent than Child-Langmuir sheath, and finally contracts to a Child-Langmuir sheath. RF effects have been measured in a parallel plasma capacitor. The results show that from DC up to 500 kHz the plasma potential profiles vary significantly. To avoid RF related complications in plasma production, a hot-filament discharge plasma in a multidiode device has been used

z:row.TitlePrimary: Pumping potential wells
z:row.TitleSecondary: NASA Conference on Double Layers in Plasmas, March 1986
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Huntsville, AL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nonmonotonic plasma potential structures are a common feature of many double layers and sheaths. In order to exist, such structures must all find a solution to a common problem. Ions created by charge exchange or ionization in the region of the potential well are electrostatically confined and tend to accumulate and fill up the potential well. The increase in positive charge should eliminate the well. Nevertheless, steady state structures are found in which the wells do not fill up. This means that it is important to take into account processes which `pump' ions from the well. As examples of ion pumping of plasma wells, the authors consider potential dips in front of a positively biased electron collecting anode in a relatively cold, low density multidipole plasma. Pumping is provided by ion leaks from the edges of the potential dip or by oscillating the applied potential. In the former case the two dimensional character of the problem is shown to be important
z:row.User2: pumping potential wells; potential structures; double layers; sheaths; charge exchange; ionization; potential well; ion pumping; electron collecting anode; low density multidipole plasma; ion leaks

z:row.TitlePrimary: Rotating field antenna experiments in Phaedrus-B
z:row.TitleSecondary: Applications of Radio-Frequency Power Plasmas - Seventh Topical Conference, 4-6 May 1987
z:row.Keyword: magnetic mirrors|plasma diagnostics|plasma heating|plasma temperature|radiofrequency heating
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kissimmee, FL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin-Madison Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The rotating field antenna in the central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror consists of two close-spaced dual half-turn ICRF antennas. The symmetry axes of the antennas are rotated 90° with respect to each other. Each antenna is driven by a separate RF amplifier, with >200 KW power output. The polarization of the resultant antenna near fields was selected by the relative phasing of the antenna currents. In particular, the antenna set can produce nearly pure left or right circularly polarized fields. The authors found an increase in the ion heating as the field polarization was varied from right circularly polarized through linear polarization to left circular polarization, for plasma densities up to 3-4×1012 cm-3, when the antenna set was driven at ω~ωci (midplane). Ion temperature was diagnosed by a time of flight neutral energy analyzer. Results are compared to the predictions of the ICRF code ANTENA of B. McVey
z:row.User2: ICRF heating; plasma density; ion temperature; rotating field antenna; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; field polarization; time of flight neutral energy analyzer

z:row.TitlePrimary: Control of fast magnetosonic modes with a phased antenna array in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: Applications of Radio-Frequency Power Plasmas - Seventh Topical Conference, 4-6 May 1987
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kissimmee, FL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The central cell of the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror is equipped with four dual half-turn ICRF antennas. The antennas are arranged in two close-spaced pairs, with the antenna pairs located 50 cm to either side of central cell midplane. In these experiments, two antennas (one from each pair) with an axial separation of 1 m are driven by separate RF amplifiers, each with >200 KW power output. The relative phase of the driven antenna currents may be fixed throughout a shot, or rapidly swept (180° in ∥ spectrum of the antenna set. They further show that the strong excitation of the m=+1 fast magnetosonic eigenmode provides stabilization against the curvature driven flute instability through ponderomotive force effects. Conversely, when the antenna phasing is chosen to suppress the m=+1 fast magnetosonic eigenmode, the plasma is MHD unstable, with density fluctuation levels on the order of δn/n=1. Results are in good agreement with predictions from the ICRF code ANTENA of B. McVey
z:row.User2: fast magnetosonic modes; phased antenna array; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; ICRF antennas; relative antenna phasing; curvature driven flute instability; ponderomotive force effects; MHD; density fluctuation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Self-similar potential in the near wake
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The plasma potential is measured near the edge of an electrically floating obstacle placed in a steady-state, supersonic, unmagnetized, neutral plasma flow. Equipotential contours show the sheath of the upstream side of the obstacle wrapping around the edge of the obstacle and fanning out into the near wake. Both fluid theory and the data find the near-wake plasma potential to be self-similar when ionization, charge exchange, and magnetic field can be neglected. The theory also finds that fluid velocity is self-similar, the near wake is nonneutral, and plasma density is not self-similar. Strong electric fields are found near the obstacle and equipotential contours are found to conform to all boundaries
z:row.User2: supersonic plasma flow; equipotential contours; near wake; plasma potential; electrically floating obstacle; neutral plasma flow; fluid theory; ionization; charge exchange; magnetic field; plasma density
