z:row.TitlePrimary: Eigenmode electric field profiles in cylindrical plasmas
z:row.Keyword: plasma density|plasma heating|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics|plasma temperature|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electric field profiles of plasma column eigenmodes in the ion-cyclotron range of frequencies are discussed. Step and parabolic density profiles are compared. The role of temperature and Alfven resonance is analyzed
z:row.User2: electric field profiles; cylindrical plasmas; plasma column eigenmodes; ion-cyclotron range of frequencies; density profiles; temperature; Alfven resonance

z:row.TitlePrimary: Steady-state ion pumping of a potential dip near an electron collecting anode
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A negative potential well is found in front of a positively biased electron collecting plate in a low temperature laboratory plasma. The well parameters are governed by the Child-Langmuir condition and a necessary condition for the existence of such potential wells is the presence of an ion pumping mechanism which removes trapped ions from the wells. Here ion pumping was provided by the presence of negative electrically floating ceramic on the back of the plate
z:row.User2: steady state; ion trapping; electron collecting anode; negative potential well; plasma; Child-Langmuir condition; ion pumping

z:row.TitlePrimary: Direct indication plasma potential diagnostic based on secondary electron emission
z:row.Keyword: electric potential|plasma probes|secondary electron emission|voltage measurement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new method of plasma potential measurement which makes use of secondary electron emission is presented. A differential secondary emission probe is employed consisting of two similar single probes, each with surfaces that have different secondary emission coefficients. The differential emission current drives a feedback control circuit (previously used with heated probes) to serve as a sensor of plasma potential. When the secondary emission coefficient of a single probe is greater than unity, the floating potential of that probe is also shown to be a good indication of plasma potential
z:row.User2: electric potential measurement; plasma potential diagnostic; secondary electron emission; differential secondary emission probe; differential emission current; feedback control circuit; floating potential

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thomson scattering electron temperature measurements in the east end cell of the Phaedrus-B Tandem Mirror plasma device
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6), 19-21 May 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6)
z:row.Keyword: magnetic mirrors|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma diagnostics|plasma temperature
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Saskatoon, Sask., Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the summer of 1985 the Phaedrus Tandem Mirror was fundamentally reconfigured to the Phaedrus-B Tandem Mirror. Choke coils and thermal barrier regions were added between the end cells and central cell. A new ICRF antenna set has been installed which consists of two dual half turn antennas in each end cell as well as four dual half turn antennas in the central cell with multiphasing capability. Also, higher end cell magnetic fields now make it possible to consider heating the electrons in the end cells at the fundamental frequency rather than the second harmonic. Critical to the understanding of this new configuration is the determination of the behavior of the electron temperature in the end cells as well as throughout the machine. High energy density in the end cells (Ti~1 keV, n~5×1012 cm-3) makes it impossible to measure the electron temperature by standard electrostatic probes. Thompson scattering, which analyzes ruby light scattered off of the end cell electrons, is used to determine the local electron temperature. Electron temperature data are presented
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-B Tandem Mirror; ICRF antenna; electron temperature; end cells; Thompson scattering; ruby light

z:row.TitlePrimary: Techniques for using emitting probes for potential measurements in RF plasma
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6), 19-21 May 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Saskatoon, Sask., Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors describe investigations of the effects of RF on plasma potential measurements with emitting probes and give methods for interpreting the data. The techniques correspond to the floating method and inflection point method of single emitting probes and differential emitting probe respectively. These methods are based on the time-averaged emitting probe I-V characteristics so the circuits are simple. It is also shown that the undistorted emissive probe characteristic can be obtained by the `following technique' in a plasma with large plasma potential fluctuations. A simple method of measurement of plasma potential fluctuation which makes use of time averaged emissive I-V characteristics is given
z:row.User2: RF plasmas; plasma potential measurements; emitting probes; floating method; inflection point method; single emitting probes; differential emitting probe; time-averaged emitting probe I-V characteristics; plasma potential fluctuation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Phased antenna experiments in the central cell of Phaedrus B
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6), 19-21 May 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Saskatoon, Sask., Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: When Phaedrus B is operated without ICRF in the end cells, MHD stability of the central cell plasma depends on ICRF-driven radial ponderomotive force effects. Stability is dependent on both near field and far field (wave propagation) effects. It has been previously observed that stability is a strong function of (ω/ωci), where ω is the ICRF frequency and ωci is the ion cyclotron frequency in the central cell (typically 8×106 rad/sec in Phaedrus B). This effect is attributed to the change in near and wave fields, and their radial gradients, as (ω/ωci) is varied through unity. The authors present experiments in which the relative phase of two antennas in the central cell is varied, thereby selecting particular wave modes, and their associated radial field profiles, for preferential excitation. Such selectivity allows investigation of ponderomotive force effects without the changes in plasma parameters associated with varying the ratio (ω/ωci). One finds that proper phasing of the antennas suppresses MHD activity in the central cell of Phaedrus B. 90° variations in the relative antenna phasing result in more than an order of magnitude change in the fluctuation level of the central cell plasma. Measurements of the field profiles and comparisons with the ANTENA code are presented
z:row.User2: ICRF heating; phased antenna experiments; central cell; Phaedrus B; ponderomotive force effects; wave modes; MHD activity; antenna phasing; field profiles; ANTENA

z:row.TitlePrimary: PUMPING POTENTIAL WELLS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Double Layers in Plasmas, Mar 1986
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Huntsville, AL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nonmonotonic plasma potential structures are a common feature of many double layers and sheaths. Steady state plasma potential wells separating regions having different plasma potentials are often found in laboratory experiments. Ions created by charge exchange or ionization in the region of the potential well are electrostatically confined and tend to accumulate and fill up the potential well. Nevertheless, steady state structures are found in which the wells do not fill up. This means that it is important to take into account processes which 'pump' ions from the well. As examples of ion pumping of plasma wells, we consider potential dips in front of a positively biased electron collecting anode in a relatively cold, low density multidipole plasma. Pumping is provided by ion leaks from the edges of the potential dip or by oscillating the applied potential. In the former case the two dimensional character of the problem is shown to be important.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: PLASMA POTENTIAL WELLS; ION PUMPING; POTENTIAL DIPS; POTENTIAL-WELL PUMPING; DOUBLE LAYERS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Shift in plasma column position produced by azimuthally asymmetric electron heating in a tandem mirror
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Large shifts in the equilibrium position of the plasma column in the Phaedrus tandem mirror [Nucl. Fusion 25, 1213 (1985)] are observed when a 25 kW, 1 msec, 15.5 GHz microwave heating pulse (ω~2ωce) is injected into one end cell of the device. The shift in the plasma column axial position occurs in all regions of the device, and is comparable in size to the initial plasma radius. The change in plasma position is a result of nonuniform electron heating produced by azimuthally asymmetric illumination of the plasma column by the microwave beam
z:row.User2: azimuthally asymmetric electron heating; tandem mirror; shifts; equilibrium position; plasma column; microwave heating pulse; plasma column axial position; plasma radius

z:row.TitlePrimary: Techniques for using emitting probes for potential measurement in RF plasmas
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Investigations of the effects of RF on plasma potential measurements with electron emitting probes and methods for interpreting data are presented. Techniques correspond to the floating and inflection point methods of single-emitting and differential emitting probes, respectively. A simple method of measurement of plasma potential fluctuations is given which makes use of time-averaged emitting probe I-V characteristics
z:row.User2: floating point; plasma diagnostics; emitting probes; potential measurement; RF plasmas; electron emitting probes; inflection point; plasma potential fluctuations; time-averaged emitting probe I- V characteristics

z:row.TitlePrimary: The use of time averaged emitting probes to study plasma processing
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6), 19-21 May 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Saskatoon, Sask., Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin-Madison Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Sheaths in capacitive RF discharges play an important role in a variety of plasma processing techniques. Recently it has been demonstrated that time averaged emitting probe characteristics can be used to determine the maximum and minimum potential value of the time varying RF potential with good spatial resolution. This allows one to determine many of the details of time varying sheath potentials. A first step in the application of this technique to plasma processing by ions energized in sheaths is presented. Sheaths in a DC multi-dipole plasma with RF coupled either with a capacitor or directly to conductors on which insulators are mounted are presented. Experimental data cover a range of frequencies and neutral pressures. An important issue considered is the value of the RF self bias of the insulator and of the plasma
z:row.User2: time averaged emitting probes; plasma processing; capacitive RF discharges; maximum; minimum potential; time varying RF potential; spatial resolution; time varying sheath potentials; RF self bias

z:row.TitlePrimary: Enhancement of the plasma potential by fluctuating electric fields near the ion cyclotron frequency
z:row.Keyword: electromagnetic wave propagation in plasma|magnetic mirrors|plasma density|plasma filled waveguides|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is found that ion cyclotron resonance frequency can create an ion-plugging plasma potential equal to several times Te/e(≃Ti/e) in the Phaedrus tandem mirror end cells or at the end of the central cell. A model based on a local balance of electron expulsion by the RF field E˜z and trapping by Coulomb scattering predicts the magnitude and scaling of the potential with density and RF antenna current. This model is in reasonable agreement with experimental observations. This ion cyclotron resonance-frequency enhanced potential increases as the plasma density decreases and as the antenna current increases
z:row.User2: plasma potential; fluctuating electric fields; ion cyclotron frequency; ion-plugging plasma potential; Phaedrus tandem mirror end cells; local balance of electron expulsion; trapping; Coulomb scattering; density; RF antenna current

z:row.TitlePrimary: Phaedrus diagnostic system
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 5th Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 16-20 Sept. 1984
z:row.Keyword: computerised instrumentation|data acquisition|plasma density|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma probes
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Tahoe City, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Phaedrus diagnostic system makes optimum use of probes and miniature gridded energy analyzers to measure detailed parameters such as density, plasma potential, and electron and ion energy. This requires miniaturization and provision for flexible access. Other diagnostics are made as flexible as possible. A multiple-aperture, end-loss analyzer is rotatable, allowing complete mapping of the end wall loss contours. Self-emissive probes are used to measure plasma potential contours in the end plugs. A single-channel neutral energy analyzer is movable and can be swept in energy. Secondary emission detector arrays supplement the neutral energy analyzer and give a measure of the ion energy versus pitch angle. Calibrated diamagnetic loops are used to measure the total plasma energy and its axial extent in each cell. Both permanent and insertable fast ion gauges are available. Completing the diagnostic system is a computerized data-acquisition system that is flexible and receptive to the time varying demands of the many ongoing experiments
z:row.User2: electron energy; self-emissive probes; plasma diagnostics; secondary emission detector array; Phaedrus diagnostic system; gridded energy analyzers; density; plasma potential; ion energy; mapping; end wall loss contours; end plugs; single-channel neutral energy analyzer; diamagnetic loops; plasma energy; ion gauges; computerized data-acquisition system

z:row.TitlePrimary: MEASUREMENT OF PLASMA PRESHEATH
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The plasma presheath in a multidipole device was measured by an emissive probe using the inflection-point method in the limit of zero emission. The temporal evolution of ion-acoustic waves was also measured. Results are compared. It is shown that the potential in the bulk of the plasma is describable by a simplified version of the plasma-sheath equation. Inclusion of finite ion temperature has a negligible effect on the predicted results compared to the inclusion of the primary electrons in the theory.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: MULTIDIPOLE DEVICES

z:row.TitlePrimary: FUELING AND HEATING OF TANDEM MIRROR END CELLS USING rf AT THE ION-CYCLOTRON FREQUENCY
z:row.Keyword: PLASMAS -- Heating|MATHEMATICAL STATISTICS - Monte Carlo Methods
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: Fueling and heating of tandem mirror end cells by rf at the ion-cyclotron frequency have been studied experimentally in the Phaedrus Tandem Mirror. The end cell density is found to increase linearly with rf voltage. The total plasma energy is observed to increase with rf power with no evidence of saturation at high power. The plasma axial length decreases with increasing rf power down to a length of approximately the distance between the two resonance locations in the end cell. The highest density and average ion energy are achieved with the resonance closest to the midplane. It is necessary to assume that the rf electric field at the resonance decreases with increasing density and with distance from the antenna in order to model the ion particle and power balance. The particle and power balance model predicts that dense, hot end cells may be maintained with E// plus approx. 1 v/cm and a fueling efficiency of a few percent when the resonance is close to the midplane because of better ion confinement and small plasma volume.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: ION CYCLOTRON RESONANCE; TANDEM MIRROR END CELLS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Review of recent laboratory double layer experiments
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Laboratory measurements of double layers are reviewed. Most experiments that are considered employed triple plasma devices or Q-machines. It is shown that a variety of both one and three dimensional phenomena have been achieved. Stationary one and three dimensional structures consist of monotonic double layers, very weak, weak, strong and very strong double layers with potential steps eφ/Te≃1, 10, and ≫10, respectively. Multiple double layers consist of structures with large potential dips on the low potential side and stairstep double layers. Two and three dimensional structures include multiple double layers, which resemble U-shaped double layers, and ionization produced strong double layers. Moving double layers include ion acoustic double layers, and double layers which are the result of drifting species and mismatches at plasma boundaries. It appears that double layers can be BGK solutions or related to turbulence. Double layer creation can occur in a variety of different ways. Ionization can sometimes be important and sometimes play no role at all
z:row.User2: triple plasma devices; Q-machines; monotonic double layers; potential dips; stairstep double layers; multiple double layers; U-shaped double layers; ionization; ion acoustic double layers; drifting species; plasma boundaries

z:row.TitlePrimary: Direct indication technique of plasma potential with differential emissive probe
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors present a new method of plasma potential measurement with a differential emissive probe. The DC heated probes are combined with a feedback loop control circuit to measure plasma potential automatically. In addition, it is shown that connecting to the central point of the filaments reduces the effect on the emissive currents of voltage drops across the filaments. The decay time constant of half-cycle heated emissive probe current during the off heating cycle is shown to depend on the initial emission current and on the bias voltage
z:row.User2: electric potential measurement; voltage measurement; plasma potential measurement; differential emissive probe; DC heated probes; feedback loop control circuit; decay time constant; emission current; bias voltage

z:row.TitlePrimary: IMPROVEMENT IN ELECTROSTATIC CONFINEMENT BY SECOND-HARMONIC ELECTRON CYCLOTRON HEATING IN THE PHAEDRUS TANDEM MIRROR
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: One minimum-B mirror end cell of the Phaedrus tandem mirror was heated with up to 30 kw of electron cyclotron heating at 107 equals 2 omega //c// omega The plug electron temperature was increased from 18 to 23 ev while a smaller temperature increase was measured in the central cell. Changes in ion end loss energy and current were consistent with direct measurements of increases in the east plug plasma potential. Ion confining potential increases of up to 27 v were observed. These increases were much greater than the T//e/e increases and in excess of that predicted by the Boltzmann relation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: PHAEDRUS TANDEM MIRROR; MIRROR REACTORS; ELECTRON CYCLOTRON HEATING; ELECTROSTATIC CONFINEMENT

z:row.TitlePrimary: Small amplitude and large amplitude double layers in laboratory plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second Symposium on Plasma Double Layers and Related Topics. Proceedings, 5-6 July 1984
z:row.TitleTertiary: Second Symposium on Plasma Double Layers and Related Topics. Proceedings
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Innsbruck, Austria
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nucl. Eng. Dept., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The evolution processes for BGK type and ion acoustic type double layers were examined in a triple plasma device. Although both types of double layers were observed to evolve on the ion time scale, the BGK type was originated in sheath-like structures while the ion acoustic type was associated with long wavelength ion waves
z:row.User2: BGK type double layers; double layers; laboratory plasmas; evolution processes; ion acoustic type double layers; triple plasma device; sheath-like structures; long wavelength ion waves

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermal barriers in tandem mirrors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second Symposium on Plasma Double Layers and Related Topics. Proceedings, 5-6 July 1984
z:row.TitleTertiary: Second Symposium on Plasma Double Layers and Related Topics. Proceedings
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Innsbruck, Austria
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nucl. Eng. Dept., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Thermal barriers are stationary potential dips in tandem mirrors. They are important because they allow the creation of ion plugging potentials by increasing the local electron temperature rather than the local plasma density. The corresponding decrease in input power increases the reactor viability of tandem mirrors. The principle problems associated with them is their creation and the pumping out of ions which tend to fill in the barriers. Tandem mirrors are complicated devices with many cells and there are many possible locations and techniques for thermal barriers. The variety of solutions that have been designed and constructed for creating the barriers and pumping them out is discussed. A comparison is given with moving and stationary multiple double layers which share some common features. Recent experimental results are also discussed
z:row.User2: tandem mirrors; potential dips; ion plugging potentials; local electron temperature; local plasma density; multiple double layers

z:row.TitlePrimary: MODIFICATION OF THE MACROSCOPIC STABILITY OF A TANDEM MIRROR BY PARTIAL LINE-TYING
z:row.Keyword: PLASMAS -- Stability|MAGNETIC FIELDS - Theory|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Stability
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Increased stability is observed during experiments with gun injection in the Phaedrus tandem mirror. This is manifested by three effects. First, a magnetic mirror cell with bad average curvature, adjacent to a plasma gun, confines plasma with betas up to 20%. Second, the central cell, also with bad curvature, is stable at betas up to 20%, exceeding the minimum-B interchange stability limit by a factor of 20. Third, the quadrupole magnetic field required for interchange stability is reduced. These effects are shown to agree with a theory of line-tying stabilization, supplemented by minimum-B stabilization.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: PHAEDRUS TANDEM MIRROR; QUADRUPOLE MAGNETIC FIELD; LINE-TYING STABILIZATION; PLASMA GUN; MINIMUM-B STABILIZATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: GAS FUELLING OF RF-SUSTAINED TANDEM MIRROR END PLUGS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The possibility of fueling pure RF-powered tandem mirror end plugs by gas puffing is considered. It is shown experimentally that gas puffing can lead to significant increases in plug density and that the details of the plug density buildup depended on the antenna locations relative to the central cell and the plug midplane. Large charge-exchange energy loss resulting from the puff gas makes it an inefficient technique for fueling high-temperature end plugs. The possibility of employing gas puffing for building up high-density end plugs composed of relatively cold ions is also considered as a means of achieving electrostatic confinement for an ICRF-stabilized central cell. Experimental enhancement of the central-cell density, which shows no significant cooling of the central cell by the colder plug plasmas, is demonstrated. The RF power requirements for refueling an ICRF-powered end plug to a given density and temperature are estimated.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: GAS PUFFING; FUELING

z:row.TitlePrimary: Laboratory evidence for ion-acoustic-type double layers
z:row.Keyword: plasma diagnostics|plasma theory|plasma transport processes|plasma waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The formation of an ion-acoustic-type double layer was observed in the laboratory for the first time. The rarefactive part of a long-wavelength ion-acoustic wave grew in amplitude because of the presence of drifting electrons. The corresponding current limitation led to the formation of the double layer
z:row.User2: ion-acoustic-type double layers; rarefactive part; long-wavelength ion-acoustic wave; amplitude; drifting electrons; current limitation

z:row.TitlePrimary: EXPERIMENTAL OBSERVATIONS OF SELF-SIMILAR PLASMA EXPANSION
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper reports the first measurements of the plasma potential profile of an expanding plasma and demonstrates clearly the self-similar behavior of such a plasma. The experimental results are consistent with self-similar solutions which assume constant electron temperature and quasineutrality in the source plasma. The accelerated ion fronts and the sheath formation of the expanding plasma into a floating boundary are also presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: SELF-SIMILAR PLASMA EXPANSION; PLASMA POTENTIAL PROFILES; COLLISIONLESS PLASMAS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Nonlinear self-contraction of electron waves
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors present laboratory evidence of modulationally unstable electron wave packets which can be described by a nonlinear geometrical optics theory. Growth times for self-contraction are found to be much faster that ion response times and the bursts do not appear to be related to Zakharov Langmuir-wave collapse
z:row.User2: electron waves; modulationally unstable electron wave packets; nonlinear geometrical optics theory; ion response times; Zakharov Langmuir-wave collapse

z:row.TitlePrimary: Non linear self contraction of electron wave packets
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record of the 1984 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received) (Cat. No. 84CH1958-8), 14-16 May 1984
z:row.TitleTertiary: Conference Record of the 1984 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received) (Cat. No. 84CH1958-8)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: St. Louis, MO, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the laboratory, electron beams are injected into the target of a triple plasma device and excite waves near the electron plasma frequency which are driven to turbulent levels. These waves are unstable to breakdown into wavepackets and experience a self contraction process. In the experiment the authors observe bursting aperiodic structures that occur on electron time scales and propagate near the electron thermal velocity and thus can not be solitons or cavitons. The rise times are too short to allow ambipolar electric fields to affect ions and generate the quasineutral density `hole' necessary for Langmuir type wave collapse. This is an example of bursting phenomena that need not be explained by the multiple time scale arguments such as the Zakharov equation formulation (1972)
z:row.User2: nonlinear self contraction; electron beam injection; plasma wave excitation; quasineutral density hole; electron wave packets; triple plasma device; electron plasma frequency; bursting aperiodic structures; electron time scales; electron thermal velocity; solitons; cavitons; ambipolar electric fields; Langmuir type wave collapse; bursting phenomena; multiple time scale; Zakharov equation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experiments on ion acoustic typed double layers
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record of the 1984 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received) (Cat. No. 84CH1958-8), 14-16 May 1984
z:row.TitleTertiary: Conference Record of the 1984 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received) (Cat. No. 84CH1958-8)
z:row.Keyword: plasma density|plasma sheaths|plasma shock waves|plasma temperature|plasma transport processes|plasma waves
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: St. Louis, MO, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The formation of small amplitude double layers with potential drops the order of the electron temperature, was examined experimentally by pulsing a grid and thereby changing the electron drift across the target chamber of a triple plasma device. The rarefactive part of a long wavelength, low frequency ion wave grew in amplitude due to the presence of slowly drifting electrons. The corresponding current limitation led to the formation of the double layers. Depending on the plasma conditions, the asymmetric double layers either transform into a weak monotonic layer, a propagating shock, or a series of rarefactive solitary pulses. The rarefactive pulses propagate with Mach number less than one and resemble solitary plasma holes with density cavities in both the electron and the ion density profiles
z:row.User2: electron density profile; ion acoustic typed double layers; potential drops; electron temperature; electron drift; triple plasma device; low frequency ion wave; slowly drifting electrons; weak monotonic layer; propagating shock; rarefactive solitary pulses; Mach number; solitary plasma holes; density cavities; ion density profiles

z:row.TitlePrimary: MEASUREMENT OF VACUUM SPACE POTENTIAL BY AN EMISSIVE PROBE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: Using the inflection point method of interpreting emissive probes, it is shown that is possible to measure the electric space potential established between two parallel metal plates in a vacuum.

z:row.TitlePrimary: EXPERIMENTAL OBSERVATIONS OF NONLINEARLY ENHANCED 2 OMEGA //U//H ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION EXCITED BY STEADY-STATE COLLIDING ELECTRON BEAMS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: Counterstreaming large-diameter electron beams in a steady-state laboratory experiment are observed to generate transverse radiation at twice the upper-hybrid frequency with a quadrupole radiation pattern. The electromagnetic wave power density is nonlinearly enhanced over the power density obtained from a single beam-plasma system. Electromagnetic power density scales exponentially with beam energy and increases with ion mass.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: SELF-EMISSIVE PROBES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: A high-density magnetized plasma is seen to heat small diameter tungsten wire probes to electron emission. The use of these self-emissive probes to determine the plasma potential in a tandem mirror plasma is investigated. A simplified model is presented and comparison is made with conventional emissive probe behavior.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Absolute power scaling measurements of electromagnetic radiation at 2ωUH generated by steady state colliding electron beams
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1983 International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 23-25 May 1983
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1983 International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: When counterstreaming electron beams are allowed to collide in the target, steady-state electrostatic and electromagnetic disturbances are observed respectively at the upper-hybrid frequency (ωUH) and the first harmonic (2ωUH). The colliding-beam EM radiation power is greatly enhanced over that of the single-beam case. The absolute conversion efficiency defined has been measured to be nem~2×10-4, substantially higher than previous pulsed experiments. EM power appears to scale exponentially with beam energy with no evidence of an upper limit saturation, or lower limit threshold
z:row.User2: electrostatic disturbances; power scaling; electromagnetic radiation; steady state colliding electron beams; counterstreaming electron beams; electromagnetic disturbances; upper-hybrid frequency; first harmonic; absolute conversion efficiency; beam energy; upper limit saturation; lower limit threshold

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental observations of self-similar plasma expansions
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1983 International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 23-25 May 1983
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1983 International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The potential profiles of an expanding plasma have been measured for the first time in experiments. The expanding source plasma is quasi-neutral, collisionless and has electron temperature (Te=2 eV) much higher than the ion temperature (Ti=0.3 eV). The measured potential profiles indicated the existence of an ion front preceding the expanding plasma; ions were accelerated to velocities much higher than the ion acoustic velocity. Sheath formation was also observed when the expanding plasma reached either a floating or grounded boundary
z:row.User2: quasineutral source plasma; collisionless plasma; sheath formation; floating boundary; self-similar plasma; potential profiles; expanding plasma; electron temperature; ion temperature; ion front; grounded boundary

z:row.TitlePrimary: RF stabilization of an axisymmetric tandem mirror
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma with significant central-cell beta can be sustained in a tandem mirror composed of three axisymmetric simple mirror cells by the use of ion-cyclotron resonant heating. Radial ponderomotive force due to the RF electric field opposes the centrifugal force due to the field-line curvature to ensure interchange stability. This is indicated by the sensitive dependence of the plasma stability on the sign of the difference between the RF frequency and the ion-cyclotron frequency
z:row.User2: axisymmetric tandem mirror; ion-cyclotron resonant heating; RF electric field; centrifugal force; field-line curvature; interchange stability; plasma stability; ion-cyclotron frequency

z:row.TitlePrimary: Electron temperature differences and double layers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electron temperature differences across plasma double layers are studied experimentally. It is shown that the temperature differences across a double layer can be varied and are not a result of thermalization of the bump-on-tail distribution. The implications of these results for electron thermal energy transport in laser-pellet and tandem-mirror experiments are also discussed
z:row.User2: double layers; temperature differences; thermalization; bump-on-tail distribution; electron thermal energy transport; laser-pellet; tandem-mirror experiments

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam-plasma interactions in a positive ion-negative ion plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An electron-free plasma consisting of negative ions (SF6-) and positive ions (Ar+), and negligible neutral-ion collision frequencies has been created in the laboratory. This plasma has a mass ratio of approximately 3.5-similar to many computer particle-in-cell simulated systems. A fluid description of this positive and negative ion confinement (PANIC) plasma is given and compared to experimental measurements of a beam-plasma instability for both beam species and a wide range of beam energies. The fluid dispersion relation and most growing modes are predicted to be insensitive to many parameters of the PANIC beam-plasma system, and found to the consistent with the data
z:row.User2: Ar+-SF6-; beam-plasma interactions; positive ion-negative ion plasma; electron-free plasma; neutral-ion collision frequencies; mass ratio; particle-in-cell simulated systems; beam-plasma instability; dispersion relation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Recent experiments in the Phaedrus tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nucelar Fusion Research. Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference, 1-8 Sept. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Baltimore, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A stable, steady tandem mirror plasma is sustained by RF alone in the Phaedrus tandem mirror experiment. RF trapping of central-cell stream provides plug fuelling and Monte Carlo simulations predict many of its characteristics. The MHD stability of the Phaedrus tandem mirror plasma is shown to be in agreement with predictions of pressure-weighted minimum-|B| stability theory. Reduction of the ion end loss flux due to electrostatic confinement of central-cell ions is observed both statically and dynamically. Direct fuelling of the plugs by gas puffing and RF trapping has also been demonstrated.-In addition, neutral-beam injection into RF-sustained plasmas is described; significant increases in diamagnetism and density have been obtained. Preliminary experiments with breakdown and heating with ECRF are also described
z:row.User2: Phaedrus tandem mirror; RF trapping; plug fuelling; Monte Carlo simulations; MHD stability; ion end loss flux; electrostatic confinement; neutral-beam injection

z:row.TitlePrimary: The effect of secondary electrons on plasma potential in a multi-dipole device
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A simple model and the corresponding experimental results show that secondary electrons emitted from the walls of a filament discharge plasma device dominate the behavior of the plasma potential at low neutral pressures
z:row.User2: secondary electrons; plasma potential; multi-dipole device; filament discharge plasma device

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dynamic electrostatic confinement in an RF-sustained tandem mirror
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Electrostatic ion confinement is demonstrated in an RF-sustained tandem mirror and shown to have a dynamic nature. Measurements of plasma potential and ion end loss on particular flux tubes show that confinement can be enhanced by a factor of 3 over direct- flow loss rates. The axial confining potential can vary with radial position and time resulting in changes in ion confinement with abrupt reductions in central-cell plasma density and axial potential confinement is reduced
z:row.User2: electrostatic ion confinement; RF-sustained tandem mirror; plasma potential; ion end loss; flow loss rates; central-cell plasma density

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of macroscopic stability limits in a tandem mirror
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A limit to the ratio of central-cell to plug β of 1.8±1.0 is measured in the Phaedrus tandem mirror for central-cell β's of 2% to 5%. This is consistent with the limiting ratio of 2.0 predicted for interchange stability, and is the first experimental test of the effect on the interchange limit from varying the plasma pressure along a magnetic field line in a tandem-mirror configuration
z:row.User2: macroscopic stability; tandem mirror

z:row.TitlePrimary: Transition from single to multiple double layers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: It is shown that laboratory double layers become multiple double layers when the ratio of Debye length to system length is decreased. This result exhibits characteristics described by boundary layer theory
z:row.User2: single double layers; plasma; multiple double layers; Debye length; system length; boundary layer theory

z:row.TitlePrimary: DETECTION OF SECONDARY ELECTRONS IN A MULTIDIPOLE PLASMA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: Secondary electrons are identified as a separate component within a plasma in a specifically modified multidipole device. It is demonstrated that secondary electron emission at walls can be comparable to electron production by ionization. It is also shown that secondary electron emission can significantly change Langmuir probe characteristics.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experiments in a tandem mirror sustained and heated solely by RF
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A tandem-mirror plasma has been sustained and heated by RF alone without the need for neutral beams. End plug density and energy are maintained by ion cyclotron-resonance heating which traps and heats a fraction of the central-cell loss stream. The central-cell plasma is maintained by gas fueling and RF heating. Magnetohydrodynamic stability limits the ratio of the central-cell to plug plasma pressure, and the central-cell electron temperature must be kept high enough for ionization. A quasi steady state is achieved that lasts much longer than the decay times of the plugs and central cell
z:row.User2: MHD stability; tandem-mirror plasma; ion cyclotron-resonance heating; ionization
